  2. The increase of larger dining venues and methods has meant a big adaptation of cruise tipping traditions.

  1. Matching ideas

Activity 12. Look at the sentence beginnings a-d. Scan the passage below and find which paragraphs include this information.

  1. Rising sea levels ...        Paragraphs:
  2. Tsunamis ...        Paragraphs:
  3. Giant waves ...        Paragraphs:
  4. Water sports ...        Paragraphs:

Giant waves: exhilaration and devastation        

  1. The Alaskan wave is believed to have been a tsunami, caused by a landslide. Italy has been hit by as many as 67 tsunamis in the past 2,000 years, though none with the devastating force of that which killed 230,000 people around the Indian Ocean on Boxing Day 2004.
  2. It's useful to distinguish between tsunamis, which are caused by geological events (such as landslides or earthquakes), and giant waves generated by weather, such as those Hamilton and Lickle ride, or the water deposited on New Orleans by Hurricane Katrina. But it is anticipated that both types will become a lot more common as a result of worldwide global warming.
  3. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the oceans now absorb more than 80 per cent of the heat added to the climate system. As the waters heat up, wind velocity increases, storm tracks become more volatile, polar ice and glaciers melt, and sea levels rise.
  4. Everything in the oceans seems to be rising: wave heights, sea levels, surface temperatures, wind speeds, storm intensities, coastal surges, tsunami risks. "Now is the time to prepare for great floods," a July 2009 editorial in New Scientist advised. "The future of the UK's coastal cities is in jeopardy due to rising sea levels," reported Lloyd's. Similarly, nine out of the world's ten largest cities are located on low-lying coastal land.
  5. But this is not new. For centuries, sailors told of the existence of monstrous waves up to 100 feet high that could appear without warning in mid-ocean, against the prevailing current and wave direction, and often in perfectly clear and calm weather. Such waves were said to consist of an almost vertical wall of water preceded by a trough so deep that it was referred to as a 'hole in the sea'. Scientists were sceptical, until the existence of freak waves was confirmed in 1995 in Norway, where an 84-foot wave occurred amid seas where the average of the tallest 33 percent of waves was 39 feet.

Activity 13. Match the sentence beginnings a-d in Activity 12 with the sentence endings 1-8. Find evidence in the passage for your answer. There is one extra sentence ending that you do not need.

  1. ... threaten many cities.
  2. ... can involve helicopters.
  3. ... have occurred in Norway.
  4. ... can be caused by earthquakes.
  5. ... are popular with TV presenters.
  6. ... are caused by increasing temperatures.
  7. ... are both dangerous and fun.
  8. ... can be caused by landslides.

  1. Exam practice

Activity 14. Matching sentence endings

Complete each sentence with the correct endings A-F from the box below Note that there may be more than one correct ending for each beginning, but that you cannot use all of the endings.

  1. Geothermal Engineering ...
  2. The geothermal industry …

In the coming months, a 170-foot-high drilling rig will transform waste ground near Redruth into a new landmark. The drill belongs to a group that is planning to develop Britain's first commercial scale geothermal plant on the site. Geothermal Engineering has chosen this part of Cornwall - once renowned for its tin and copper - because of its geology. It sits on a bed of granite whose temperature can reach 200° C. Water will be pumped deep underground and will return to the surface as steam, which will power turbines to generate electricity.

"Cornwall is a real hotspot. It is like someone has put a power station below ground and you are simply tapping into it," said Ryan Law, founder and managing director of Geothermal Engineering.

Law, a former consultant to the geothermal industry, plans to have three wells at the plant, which together he estimates will produce 10 M W of electricity, enough to power 20,000 homes, and 55 M W of thermal energy, capable of heating ten hospitals 24 hours a day. The challenge is that the rock is 4.5 kilometres below the Earth's surface, meaning that months of precise drilling will be required before any energy is produced. The company has a head start. In 1976, the government-funded Hot Dry Rock Research Project began deep drilling to study the area's geology. Law plans to use the detailed maps the team produced over fifteen years to direct his efforts.

Geothermal energy is not new. The world's first conventional geothermal power station, in southern Tuscany, has been producing electricity for almost 100 years. In Iceland, a quarter of the country's electricity comes from geothermal power. Investment in geothermal projects in Australia is expected to reach $2 billion (£1.3 billion) by 2014. The industry is also well established in America and Germany. In Britain, schemes are under way in Southampton and Newcastle.

Conventional geothermal power relies on naturally occurring steam pockets near the Earth's surface so it tends to be confined to volcanically active regions or areas close to fault lines. Law claims the process his company uses removes this limitation, making the industry viable almost anywhere in the world.

However, despite billions of pounds in public and private investment and a raft of big projects, the industry has so far failed to demonstrate it can fulfil its promise. Critics argue it is costly, reliant on high-risk, time-consuming drilling and struggles to produce large amounts of energy capable of making a real contribution to the world's needs. Law refuses to let such doubts dampen his ambitions. "What other renewable energy gives you 24-hour supply? The potential is enormous and we are planning another 25 plants."

Glossary:

geothermal: relating to the internal heat of the earth

  1. There is a chance of         rain in this morning and some areas might flood.
  2. There are                 winds on the coast, so be very careful if walking near the cliffs.
  3. There have been          floods in the south and many people have had to leave their homes.
  4. The north has been affected by                 snow, and many people are stuck at home.
  5. Today will be sunny with          blue skies.
  6. There is         fog in the west and driving might be dangerous.
  7. There will be          temperatures today, so make sure you drink lots of water.
  8. We advise people not to take their children out in the          heat.

Activity 4. Underline the odd one out in the groups of words 1-4 below and say why it is different.

e.g. cool / hot / warm / balmy / rainy

'Rainy' is different: it does not describe temperature.

  1. precipitation / moisture / humidity / atmosphere
  2. global warming /climate change / greenhouse effect / ozone layer
  3. tidal wave / hurricane / cyclone / gale
  4. fog / haze / mist / drizzle

  1. Sequencing words

In the Listening exam, you need to understand the sequence (or order) of ideas and/or events.

Activity 5. Put the sequencing words and phrases in the correct column in the table. Some can go into more than one column.

Activity 6. Complete the passage below with the words a-h.

  1. during
  2. initially
  3. next
  4. prior
  5. simultaneously
  6. the next step
  7. ultimately
  8. when

Preparing for a heat wave

Make sure you are always prepared for any kind of extreme weather (1)         to it occurring. You can do this by checking the weather forecast regularly. Heat waves can often be predicted days and even weeks in advance. Heat waves are

(2)         seen as fun, a chance to get outside in the sun, and a hazard, which can cause illness. Make sure you drink plenty of water (3)         this time, otherwise you may become dehydrated. (4)                 you feel hot, try to find some shade.

It is also important to watch for signs of heatstroke. A person may (5)         become slow and lethargic, and (6)

        become confused or incoherent. If you see these second symptoms, get the person into the shade immediately and give them water. If the symptoms do not go away instantly, (7)

        would        be        to        call        an        ambulance.        If        left        untreated,        heatstroke        can        (8)

        lead to death.

Activity 7. Underline the correct words in sentences 1-6.

  1. Many people do not believe that pollution has disastrous long-term effects on the environment, but eventually / finally they will have to accept the overwhelming evidence.
  2. There was no former / prior warning of the storm; it took everyone by surprise.
  3. I was the only person standing under the large tree during / when the rain came so I was lucky and didn't get wet.
  4. Here is the weather forecast for today. Initially / Previously it will be sunny, but cloud will develop later in the afternoon.
  5. If a hurricane strikes, the first thing to do is get inside. Next / The next step you should shut all the windows and doors.
  6. The effects of global warming will be seen in the future, eventually / ultimately leading to a large rise in sea levels and eventually / ultimately flooding vast areas of land.

  1. Skills development
  1. Understanding classification

LESSON 6 – READING LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION

  1. Language development
  1. Body language

Activity 1. Match the words a-g in the box with the photos 1-6. There is one extra word.

Activity 2. Complete sentences 1-10 with the correct form of the verbs in Activity 1, or the verbs nod, shake, and wave.

  1. I could tell she was feeling happy, because she was        .
  2. He         his head again and explained that there were no more tickets.
  3. There were some people in the distance. One of them was shouting and         at us.
  4. My little sister always         me with her elbow when she has something funny to say.
  5. Mike liked the proposal and was         his head throughout the meeting.
  6. The audience were         very loudly when the musicians came on stage.
  7. Tom didn't know the answer to the question, so he just         his shoulders.
  8. I knew he was joking and the story wasn't true, because he         at me first.
  9. Don't         at people with your finger - it is very impolite and aggressive.
  10. I knew I wasn't going to get a good mark. My teacher was         while she was reading my essay.

  1. Prefixes

Learning prefixes is a useful way to work out the meaning of specific details. Think about the meaning of the base word and then apply the meaning of the prefix: illegal entry = an entry that is the opposite of legal, so the entry is not legal.

Activity 3. Put the verbs from Activity 1 and 2 into the correct category

positive

negative

shake heads

neutral

Activity 4. Read the passage and look at the words in bold. Match the prefix of the word with their meanings.

  1. not:
  2. leave or remove:
  3. not or the opposite:
  4. not correct:

  1. Collocations with sign

Learning word patterns, like which prepositions follow a verb, is another simple way to increase your lexical knowledge. It will help you understand the meaning of sentences and details in the exam.

Activity 5. Match the sentence beginnings 1-5 with the sentence endings a-e. In which sentence is sign a noun?

  1. In agreeing to the contract, they signed
  2. I have to stay at home because I need to sign
  3. Regrettably, there is no sign
  4. I really need faster internet, so I'm going to sign
  5. All delegates must sign

  1. of progress with the repair work.
  2. in before they can enter the conference hall.
  3. for an important delivery.
  4. away their rights to compensation.
  5. up for the broadband offer.
  1. Skills development

  1. Summarising texts

Activity 6. Read the passage and choose the best summary.

  1. Communication skills are not only important to the success of the business, but also to employees within the business.
  2. A good manager will respond to customers' questions and needs, and help them choose the most suitable product.

  1. The key to good communication is to pay attention to what other people have to say. Good communicators are definitely not those who like the sound of their own voice. Forget the gift of the gab; communication is all about establishing a rapport with your customers, work colleagues or boss.
  2. The ability to sell is the ultimate test of communication skills. But in the modern world salesmen do not sell, customers choose to buy, says Jon Naylor, the customer service director of PC World. “You have to empathize with the customer and build a relationship. Listening to the information given and asking the right questions is very important’’
  3. Not listening costs money in the world of sales - returned goods, refunds and the loss of repeat custom. But the ability to listen is as important on the top floor as it is on the shop floor and can have just as profound an effect on the bottom line of a business’ finances. “If you ask what makes a good manager, people almost always say ‘they listen to what we have to say and consider our needs”, says Dr Paul Dobson, a senior lecturer at Cass Business School.
  4. Dr Dobson gives MBA students lessons in ‘active listening’, which is listening and asking appropriate questions, then clarifying and responding to the answers. “The fundamental thing is to listen to what people say, which means that you have to be motivated to want to know the answers,” Dr Dobson says.
  1. Matching information

Activity 7. Read the passage again and match the ideas to the paragraphs. There is one extra idea.

  1. Identifying key words

Activity 8. Underline the key words or phrases in questions 1-4.

  1. Why has it been difficult to establish a link between the calls of monkeys and people's musical preferences?
  2. What do monkeys prefer: music or silence?
  3. Is it true that monkeys appeared calmer when listening to the rock band Metallica?
  4. Who suggested this new kind of study to Professor Snowdon?

  1. Summarising information

Write very short notes about the ideas of each paragraph. It will help you locate the relevant information for each question.

Activity 9. Read extracts 1-3 and write short notes to summarise each extract.

Example:

Summary: Human musical appreciation comes from primate calls? Hard to test - don't react to music.

  1. The findings suggest that the historical roots of human appreciation of music may stretch deep into our evolutionary past, to the common ancestors we share with monkeys.
  2. When monkeys have been played music, from classical to rock, they generally prefer silence. The sole exception has come from one experiment in which monkeys appeared to be calmed down by listening to the rock band Metallica.
  3. Professor Snowdon took his new experimental approach to the subject at the suggestion of David Teie, who also works at the University of Maryland.

Activity 10. Match your short notes on extracts 1-3 (and the example) in Activity 9 with questions 1-4 in Activity 8.

  1. Locating and understanding information

Activity 11. Underline the key words in questions 1-3. Then scan the passage below and answer the questions.

  1. What made the sounds on the recorded song for the monkeys in the experiment?
  2. What behaviour did the monkeys display when they were played the 'threat' song?
  3. What happened when the monkeys were played a calming song?

When Mr Teie listened to the calls made by the cotton-top tamarin colony kept at the Wisconsin- Madison psychology department, he immediately recognised emotional states. He said, “This is a call from an animal that is not relaxed, this is from an animal that is more relaxed”, Professor Snowdon said.

Mr Teie then used these insights to compose music using features he had noticed in the monkeys’ calls, such as rising and falling pitch and the typical length of particular sounds. His aim was to produce 30-second ‘songs’ that were tuned to the tamarins’ musical sense, rather than to the human ear.

The first piece Mr Teie wrote contained rhythmic, staccato beats, based on the type of calls tamarins use to indicate a threat or stress. The second piece featured long, melodic tones, with a descending pitch, that was more like the calming, ‘affective’ calls the monkeys use during bonding behaviour. All were recorded using the cello and the human voice.

When the monkeys were played the ‘threat’ song, they moved around more and showed more anxious and social behaviour, all of which are signs of heightened alertness. The monkeys were also more likely to face towards the hidden speaker from which the music was played. The ‘affective’ song, by contrast, led to less movement and social behaviour, calmer reactions, and

Activity 12. Underline the key words in questions 1-4. Then scan the passage above and answer the questions.

  1. What is innovative about the predictive texting system that has been developed by Sanjay Patel?
  2. What types of hardware and software could work differently in the future because of this invention?
  3. What characteristics of the new systems make them fascinating for the general public?
  4. Why is this invention important to Scotland?

Activity 13. Read the passage and choose ONE correct answer for the questions 1-4. Use your answers from Activity 12 to help you.

  1. What is innovative about the predictive texting system that has been developed by Sanjay Patel?
  1. It can help his disabled brother.
  2. It uses guesswork.
  3. It processes language very fast.
  4. It works in a way that is unique to each writer.

  1. What types of hardware and software could work differently in the future because of this invention?
  1. mobile phones, PCs, e-mail, text messaging, word-processing
  2. AdapTex intelligence systems
  3. mobile phones and computers
  4. telecoms and finance

  1. What characteristics of the new systems make them fascinating for the general public?
  1. It completely changes the way people do things.
  2. It works with what people already do and makes it better.
  3. It can help disabled people.
  4. It reduces physical activity.

  1. The invention is also significant to Scotland because
  1. the country made his family feel welcome.
  2. it has given Patel a home.
  3. there are business network links with the USA.
  4. the country helped him become successful.

actual physical activity. So in 1997 I started working on creating a piece of software for the mass market that would learn your language traits. It made me realize how inefficient we were when it comes to writing information with e-mail, text messaging, and word-processing on a keyboard. Everybody wants to go faster, so they build the technologies to move faster; what hasn’t changed is the human ability to use that technology more effectively”, he said.

“We don’t want to change people’s practices, we have to complement or improve them. But you can’t expect people to change unless you make things better, simpler to use and non-intrusive. I think that’s why AdapTex intelligence systems are creating such interest.”

Over the past 15 years, Patel has worked within systems architecture in telecoms and finance. He worked for Nucleus Consulting and project-managed the setting-up of a system for the Merchants’ Exchange of St Louis, under the guidance of the Chicago Board of Trade. He completed the two-year contract in a little over a year.

Today Sanjay Patel lives in Partick in Glasgow. Previously from Croydon, he was encouraged to move to Scotland by the prospect of support from Scottish Enterprise, Scottish Development International and by the availability of specialist facilities at the Innovation Centre.

Patel’s software takes the predictive text used on mobile phones to the next level: “A mobile phone is predictive, which uses guesswork, it isn’t natural. What we have created is pre-emptive because it is relevant and uses the context. It learns and reshapes itself dynamically. It is about recognition of the patterns you use and is therefore unique to the user. It remodels itself from any document to reflect the author’s natural vocabulary, language traits and topics.’ he said.

Patel’s family arrived in the UK in the 1970s after leaving Uganda. He was brought up in London and, even before his brother’s accident, he was fascinated with the science of language patterns. “The great selling point is that this pre-empts text in any language because it recognises the patterns”, he said.

Patel is now in discussions with several large international companies interested in incorporating AdapTex into their next-generation computers. “Some are more cautious than others, but we are on the verge of signing with one of the big PC makers, and hopefully this will mean that they all follow suit”, said Patel.

He is delighted with the support he has been given in Scotland. “I came because people understood what I was talking about. The business network here, through Global Scot, has given me introductions to the highest levels in the USA. This has been imperative.”

  1. Exam practice Activity 14.

Choose ONE answer from the letters A-D.

  1. Complex information
  1. can only be communicated by human beings.
  2. is described as having awareness and being based on context.
  3. is communication across species.
  4. is too difficult for Campbell's monkeys to understand properly.

  1. Chimpanzees
  1. are not as intelligent as birds.
  2. can be taught language.
  3. can play the keyboard.
  4. have the language skills of a four-year old child.

  1. Birds have shown evidence of being able to
  1. teach themselves to solve problems.
  2. use multiple tools better than humans do.
  3. read numbers as well as people do.
  4. sleep better after taking tests.

The researchers found that the calls could be understood by other species of monkey as well as by some birds. "What our discovery showed is that the alarm calls were far more complex than we had thought," said Zuberbuhler. "They were conveying information that was contextual, self-aware and intelligent. We then tried playing these calls back to other monkeys and they responded in ways that showed they knew the meaning. What's more, the same calls would be recognised by other species, like Campbell's monkeys."

Among scientists, the idea that animals and birds might be sentient has been around a long time. Researchers at Georgia State University's language research centre in Atlanta taught chimps to use voice synthesisers and a keyboard to hold conversations with humans. One chimp developed a 3,000-word vocabulary and tests suggested she had the language and cognitive skills of a four- year-old child.

Perhaps the most surprising signs of intelligence have been found in birds, with many species showing powerful memories and reasoning power. A few years ago, Irene Pepperberg of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology taught a parrot to recognise and count up to six objects and describe their shapes.

Last year that was topped by Alex Kacelnik, a professor of behavioural ecology at Oxford, who discovered that crows are capable of using multiple tools in complex sequences, the first time such behaviour had been observed in non-humans. In an experiment seven crows successfully reeled in a piece of food placed out of reach using three different lengths of stick. Crucially, they were able to complete the task without any special training, suggesting the birds were capable of a level of abstract reasoning and creativity normally associated only with humans.

Last week it emerged that researchers from Padua University in Italy had found that birds were able to read numbers from left to right, as humans do, and count to four even when the line of numbers was moved from vertical to horizontal. They also showed that birds performed better in tests after a good night's sleep.

Glossary

species: a class of plants or animals whose members have the same main characteristics and are able to breed with each other

peer: (here) members of the same species)

sentient: capable of experiencing things through its senses

LESSON 6 – LISTENING LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION

  1. Language development

  1. Words related to communication

Activity 1. Match the words 1-10 with the definitions a-j.

  1. eloquent        a        an expression, often found in literature, that describes a person or object by referring to something that is considered to have similar characteristics to that person or object
  2. epigram        b        good at speaking and able to persuade people
  3. idiom        c        very informal language that is usually spoken rather than written, used especially by particular groups of people
  4. illiterate        d        a long speech which is spoken by one person as an entertainment, or as part of an entertainment such as a play

5. jargon

e

a group of words in a fixed order that have a particular meaning that is different from the meanings of each word

on its own

6. metaphor

f

unable to express yourself easily or well in speech

7. monologue

g

a short saying or poem which expresses an idea in a very

clever and amusing way

8. nuance

h

special words and phrases that are used by particular

groups of people, especially in their work

9. slang

t

not knowing how to read or write

10. inarticulate

j

a small difference in sound, feeling, appearance, or

meaning

Activity 2. Match the words connected to language 1-6 to the examples a-f.

1        language

a

It's raining cats and dogs.

2        dialect

b

Cockney

3        slang

c

German

4        idiom

d

America is a melting pot.

5        metaphor

e

Happy birthday

6        collocation

f

Our holiday was dead good.

Activity 3. Underline the correct word in italics in sentences 1-6.

  1. A(n) dialect / accent is a form of a language that is spoken in a particular area.
  2. People who cannot hear use sign language / semaphore to communicate.
  3. Rhetoric / Metaphor is the skill or art of using language effectively.
  4. The nuances / connotations of a word are the ideas or qualities which it makes you think of.
  5. A transcription / tracing of a conversation or speech is a written text of it, based on a recording or notes.
  6. A person who is bilingual / illiterate can speak two languages equally well, usually because they learned both languages as a child.

  1. Language for agreement and disagreement

Sometimes people use certain adjectives or adverbs to express their opinion. This is one way of understanding if speakers agree or disagree.

LESSON 7 – SPEAKING GENERAL SPEAKING STRATEGIES

  1. Introduction to IELTS speaking part 1

The Speaking test is a short, face-to-face interview with an examiner that lasts between 11 and 14 minutes.

There are three parts to complete and they become progressively more challenging.

Part 1: Introduction and questions on familiar topics

Length: 4–5 minutes

The examiner will start by introducing him or herself and asking you to state your name and show your identification.

Next, you will be asked general questions about yourself such as where you live or what you are currently doing (working or studying).

The remaining questions in this section are of a personal nature and topics will be familiar, for example, about the music you like, cooking, the weather, or movies you prefer. Usually you cover one or two more topics and you may get two or three questions about each of them.

The examiner will ask the question and then just listen, although you may be prompted to extend your response with a “why” or “why not” if your answer is too short. This is not a conversation though; it happens in a question-answer format.

Tips for doing well in Part 1:

  • Be prepared to answer questions using different verb tenses and forms.

If you listen carefully to what the examiner asks, it will help you formulate your answer using the appropriate tense.

If you are asked: Did you like the same movies when you were a child? You could say: “When I was a child, I liked cartoons more because...”

  • Don’t give one or two word answers. Give at least one or two sentences. This is your chance to show off your English and holding back is not going to help your score.
  • Prepare for this section by reviewing vocabulary about work, school, your home, hobbies, the weather, etc.

  1. General speaking strategies

Work with your partner. Answer the question "What kind of food do you like?"

  1. Strategy 1: Divide into 2 or 3 parts.

This strategy involves giving 2 or 3 reasons for your answer, as follows:

Well, there are three kinds of food that I'm really keen on. The one I like best is Italian food because I am a big fan of pasta. I also really like to eat Korean food as it's very healthy and flavorsome. I'm also kind of into Mexican food because it is so hot and spicy.

1st idea: Italian food 2nd idea: Korean food 3rd idea: Mexican food

So a complete response might look something like this:

Activity 1: Work in pairs. Answer the questions below:

  • What are your favorite foods?
  • What are some traditional foods in your country?
  • Describe a restaurant that you often go to.

Guided practice: What is your favorite food?

  • Step 1: Come up with 2 to 3 independent ideas for your answer

Italian cuisine, traditional Japanese dishes

  • Step 2: Start with a lead-in phrase, then say how many types your answer will include

Well, you know, there are 2 kinds of food I would like to mention.

  • Step 3: Add the first point with detail

Italian cuisine- flavors and combination of ingredients

  • Step 4: Add the second point with detail

Traditional Japanese dishes- simplicity and attention to detail

Sample answer: Well, you know, there are 2 kinds of food I would like to mention. The first thing I should mention is Italian cuisine because its rich flavors and exquisite combinations of ingredients truly captivate my taste buds. On top of that I can also add traditional Japanese dishes as the simplicity and attention to detail in their culinary traditions never cease to amaze me.

cuisine (n): ẩm thực flavor (n): hương vị exquisite (adj): tinh tế

ingredient (n): nguyên liệu

taste buds (n): vị giác - captivate taste buds: đánh thức vị giác

culinary (adj): liên quan, thuộc về nấu nướng

  1. Strategy 2: General to specific

This strategy involves giving a general reason for your answer, and then explaining it more specifically, and even giving an example as follows:

Well, I'd have to say that I'm a big fan of seafood. In particular, I really like to eat Japanese seafood because it's always so fresh. For instance, sashimi is delicious because the raw fish is so flavorsome.

general: seafood

specific detail: Japanese seafood

example: sashimi

So a complete response might look something like this:

Activity 2. Work in pairs. Answer the questions below:

  • Have you ever tried foreign food?
  • Do you like to try new food?
  • What kinds of new foods have you tried recently?

Guided practice: Have you ever tried foreign food?

  • Step 1: Come up with a general reason

yes- crucial for expanding one's culinary horizons and cultural knowledge

  • Step 2: Explain it more specifically

my first taste of Indian cuisine during a cultural festival in my city

  • Step 3: Give an example

dishes like butter chicken and biryani

Sample answer: Generally speaking, I would say that I have had the pleasure of trying foreign food, which I believe is crucial for expanding my culinary horizons and cultural knowledge. In particular, I vividly remember my first taste of Indian cuisine during a cultural festival in my city. For example, dishes like butter chicken and biryani captivated me with its aromatic spices and diverse flavors.

expand one’s horizon: mở rộng chân trời kiến thức

vivid (adj): sống động

aromatic (adj): thơm (hương vị)

spice (n): gia vị

  1. Strategy 3: DEPENDS

This strategy involves giving different reasons for different situations for your answer, as follows:

I think it depends, really. If I'm working I prefer to get something like fast food such as McDonalds because I only have a short break. But, if I'm out with friends, I would rather have something more exotic such as Thai food or Indian food.

2 different situations: work- hangout with friends

Your answer is going to compare two different situations or conditions. These can be quite flexible. Here are some possible ideas to use:

The 1st situation

The 2nd situation

Weekdays

Weekends

Summer

Winter

Good weather

Bad weather

Term time

School holidays

If I’m alone …

If I’m with friends …

If I’ve got a lot of time …

If I’m fairly busy …

Activity 3: Work in pairs. Answer the questions below:

  • How often do you eat out in restaurants?
  • When do you like to go out to eat?
  • Where do you eat most often?

Guided practice: How often do you eat out?

  • Step 1: Select a “depends” phrase

I think I would have to say that it is really depends

  • Step 2: Introduce the first situation

have a busy week- eat out more frequently

  • Step 3: Introduce the second situation

have more free time- eat out only once or twice a week

Sample answer: I think I would have to say that it really depends. If I have a busy week with long working hours, I find myself eating out more frequently, perhaps three to four times a week, as it provides convenience and saves time. However, if I have more free time and prefer a healthier and cost-effective option, I tend to cook at home and eat out only once or twice a week.

  1. Strategy 4: Concession

This strategy involves making a main point and then giving a counterargument to it, as follows:

Well, recently I'd have to say that I have been enjoying eating steak and each time I feel like a steak, I go to Outback Steak House because the steaks there are huge. However, I think that it may not be all that healthy to eat so much red meat, as I've heard it can lead to high levels of cholesterol.

Main point: enjoy eating steak

Counterargument: not be all that healthy

Activity 4. Work in pairs. Answer the questions below:

  • Do you have a healthy diet?
  • Do you like tasting new food?
  • Do you think Vietnamese people's diet is healthy?

Guided practice: Do you have a healthy diet?

  • Step 1: Introduce a main point

yes- maintain a healthy diet

  • Step 2: Introduce a counterargument

treat myself to indulgent foods

Sample answer: Well, I'd have to say that I make conscious efforts to maintain a healthy diet by incorporating a variety of fruits, vegetables, and lean proteins into my meals. However, I must

admit that sometimes I treat myself to indulgent foods that go against a strictly healthy eating regimen.

lean protein (np): thịt nạc protein indulgent food (np): món ăn khoái khẩu eating regimen (np): chế độ ăn uống

  1. Strategy 5: Avoidance

This strategy involves not directly answering the question at first, and then answering it, as follows:

Well, to be honest, I don't really have a favorite food, but I guess that if I had to choose one,

then I'd go for something like pizza-you know, I just love all that cheese and tomato sauce.

Avoidance: I don't really have a favorite food

Answer: I'd go for something like pizza-you know

Activity 5. Work in pairs. Answer the questions below:

  • Are there any types of food you don't like?
  • What is your favourite cuisine?
  • What types of food do you like to eat?

Guided practice: Are there any types of food you don't like?

  • Step 1: Introduce an “avoidance”

don’t really hate anything

  • Step 2: Introduce a counterargument

not really into spicy food

Sample answer: Well, to be honest, I don't hate any kind of food, but I guess that if I had to choose one, then I'd say that I’m not really into spicy food, especially in the summer.

LESSON 7 – WRITING LINE GRAPH

  1. Understanding Line graphs

A line graph consists of 1 or more lines representing the change of a particular object over time. The change of each object will be represented by a line. Unlike other types of charts in IELTS, line graphs always change over time. Therefore, you need to consider the timeline and use it accordingly. To read line graphs, there is only one way to read, which is to read from left to right along the time axis of each line corresponding to each object to clearly see their changing trend.

There are two types of line charts:

  • Less than 3 lines: This pattern is very rare in exam papers. For this type, we need to focus on comparing two lines with each other associated with the time element to clarify the trend of increasing or decreasing, staying the same, or fluctuating. It can be said that this is the easiest form of the line graph.

  • More than 3 lines: In IELTS test papers from 2017 onwards, it is common to use a line chart with more than 3 lines.

You should focus on describing the changing trends of each subject with appropriate, accurate words and structures. When writing, you need to select important information and avoid putting all the data in the chart into the article so that the article is not written endlessly and wastes time.

  1. How to write

  1. Writing an introduction

The "introductory sentence" can be understood as the opening part in IELTS Writing Task 1, as it is the first sentence intended to introduce the content depicted in the chart to the reader. The introductory sentence typically consists of just one concise sentence but provides sufficient information about the chart type, topic, units of measurement, time frame, categories, etc.

To write an introductory sentence, candidates need to closely follow the prompt. However, candidates should absolutely avoid copying the prompt verbatim and instead find alternative ways to paraphrase it.

For example: The graph below shows average carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions per person in the United Kingdom, Sweden, Italy and Portugal between 1967 and 2007.

The graph

shows

average carbon dioxide emissions per person

in the United Kingdom, Sweden,

Italy, Portugal

between 1967

and 2007

The line graph

compares

the emissions of carbon

dioxide of an average person

in four European nations

from 1967 to

2007

Introduction: The line graph compares the emissions of carbon dioxide of an average person in four European nations from 1967 to 2007

  1. Writing an overview

In paragraph 2 of your Task 1 answer, you need to write a general overview of the main trends and most important information in the graph. Don't write any numbers or percentages in this paragraph.

PRACTICE 1

Look at the graph about bakeries below and discuss these questions.

  1. What was the general trend for the earnings of the three bakeries?
  2. Which were the most popular bakeries in 2000 and in 2010?
  3. Is there anything else you could talk about in the overview?

The graph shows data about the annual earnings of three bakeries in London, 2000-2010.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

PRACTICE 2

Match the two halves of these phrases for describing general trends.

  1. There was a significant upward trend        a trend in the income of Lovely Loaves.

  1. The earnings of Lovely Loaves saw        b. significantly over the period.

  1. There was a downward        c. in the income of Bernie's Buns.

  1. The income of Bernie's Buns fluctuated        d. a dramatic increase in the last five

years.

  1. The income of Robbie's Bakery witnessed        e. a considerable fall over the period.

PRACTICE 3

Read this overview and find synonyms for the phrases below.

Overall, what stands out from the graph is that there were considerable upward trends in the income of both Bernie's Buns and Robbie's Bakery, while the earnings of Lovely Loaves saw a substantial fall over the period in question.

  1. in general overall
  2. it can be seen that         
  3. the income of Bernie's Buns and Robbie's Bakery rose         
  4. whereas         
  5. the income of Lovely Loaves went down significantly         
  6. the time period covered by the graph         

PRACTICE 4

Add the words from the box on the left to the correct places in this sample overview.

what

Overall, stands out from the graph that there were considerable trends in the income of both Bernie's Buns and Robbie's Bakery, the earnings of Lovely Loaves a substantial fall over the in question. Another interesting point is that Lovely Loaves the most popular bakery in 2000, but in 2010 Robbie's Bakery earned more money the others.

PRACTICE 5

Write an overview for the graph below.

The graph compares employment rates in three sectors of the economy, in the UK, 2000-2010.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

  1. Language to describe changes

  1. Verbs and adverbs

In paragraphs 3 and 4, you will need to have a good range of grammar and vocabulary to describe the changes in the graph, including the use of verbs and adverbs, e.g. The income of Lovely Loaves rose slightly.

Movement

Verb

go up grow improve increase

rise

double jump rocket

shoot up

soar

surge

decline decrease drop

fall

go down

halve plummet plunge

level off

remain stable

fluctuate

hit/reach a peak

bottom out

Verbs that describe big increases or decreases, like soared or plummeted, don't need an adverb, because we already know that they describe a large change. However, other verbs need an adverb, to tell the reader what kind of increase or decrease you are talking about.

PRACTICE 6

Which of the adverbs in the box below describe:

  1. a big change? dramatically
  2. a small change?
  3. a medium-size change?
  4. a fast change?
  5. a slow change?
  6. a comment by the writer?
  7. a consistent increase or decrease?

considerably

dramatically

gradually

marginally

negligibly

rapidly

remarkably

sharply

significantly

slightly

steadily

strikingly

PRACTICE 7

Look again at the graph in PRACTICE 1 and complete these sentences with a suitable verb and adverb.

  1. The income of Bernie's Buns.        between 2006 and 2008.
  2. The amount of money earned by Robbie's Bakery        between 2008 and 2010.
  3. Earnings of Lovely Loaves.        between 2004 and 2005.

  1. Adjectives and nouns

You can also describe changes using adjectives and nouns. Most of the vocabulary is the same, but you need to learn the adjective and noun forms.

There was a considerable rise in the income of Robbie's Bakery.

The income of Robbie's Bakery saw / experienced / witnessed a considerable rise.

PRACTICE 8

Complete this table with the noun forms of the verbs.

past simple verb

noun

past simple verb

noun

rose

fluctuated

fell

plunged

levelled off

decreased

declined

dipped

soared

recovered

plummeted

jumped

increased

surged

dropped

grew

In most cases, to form an adjective, you just need to remove the -ly from the adverb, e.g. sharply- sharp. In some cases, you need to change the spelling of the adjective a little bit.

PRACTICE 9

Write the adjectival form of these adverbs. Check your spelling in a dictionary.

  1. dramatically dramatic
  2. steadily
  3. considerably
  4. negligibly
  5. remarkably

  1. Prepositions

  • With started and finished, use at

Example: Income started at £55,000.

  • With increases or decreases, use (from)…to

Example: There was a sharp rise (from £40,000) to £70,000.

  • With remained stable and levelled off, use at

Example: Income remained stable at £65,000.

  • With peaked, use at

Example: Income peaked at £120,000.

  • To describe how much something increases or decreases, use by with verb and of with noun

Example: The figure went up by around £30,000. There was a slight increase of £30,000.

  • To describe the range of fluctuation, use between…and

Example: Earnings fluctuated between £80,000 and £90,000.

PRACTICE 10

Read this paragraph and choose the correct prepositions.

As regards Robbie's Bakery, income started 1 to / at £55,000 in 2000 and remained stable 2 at / to this figure 3 during / until 2005. At this point, there was a sharp rise 4 to / at £70,000. Between 2007 and 2008, the figure went up 5 to / by around £30,000, 6 to / from £70,000 7 at / to nearly £100,000. Finally, income grew gradually, and peaked 8 at / to £105,000 in 2010. If we look at Lovely Loaves, earnings fluctuated 9 between / at £80,000 and £90,000 in the first five years, and then there was a sharp fall 10 to / at £40,000 in 2008. Finally, the figure levelled off 11 to / at £40,000, and finished 12 to / at the same figure.

  1. Structures to describe changes

The graph shows data about the annual earnings of three bakeries in London, 2000-2010.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

Sometimes in the exam, you can be asked to write about a graph with a future trend. You should write your answer in the same way as before, but instead of using the past simple, change the grammar and use future tenses.

Try to use academic phrases for describing future trends to make your writing more interesting. For example:

Structure 1. [X] is / are expected / estimated / predicted to + verb + adverb

The number of students of Spanish is expected to rise significantly.

Structure 2. It is expected / estimated / predicted that [X] will + verb + adverb

It is estimated that the number of students of Spanish will rise significantly.

PRACTICE 11

Write a sentence with an adjective and noun to describe each of these changes in the graph above.

  1. Bernie's Buns, 2006-2008

There was a considerable rise in Bernie's Buns’ income.

  1. Robbie's Bakery, 2007-2008

  1. Bernie's Buns, 2001-2002

  1. Lovely Loaves, 2004-2005

PRACTICE 12

Rewrite these sentences, changing them to verb-adverb or adjective-noun.

  1. Sales of DVDs in the UK rose sharply between 2001 and 2004.

There was a sharp rise in sales of DVDs in the UK between 2001 and 2004.

  1. Chocolate production in Colombia saw a significant fall. Chocolate production in Colombia ...................................... .
  2. There was a steady growth in average incomes in Europe between 1998 and 2004. Average incomes in Europe        between 1998 and 2004.

  1. Joining two changes together

In paragraphs 3 and 4, you need to join changes together into longer sentences.

Income remained stable between 2000 and 2004, and then there was a steady rise in the next two years.

There are lots of ways you can join two ideas together in an interesting way.

PRACTICE 13

Join these changes together using the linking phrase in brackets. Make any other necessary changes.

  1. Income began at just over £80,000. Income went up slightly to £95,000 in 2001. (and then).

Income began at just over £80,000, and then it went up slightly to £95,000 in 2001.

  1. There was a steady fall to £80,000. Income recovered to £90,000 in 2004. (after which)

  1. Earnings dropped sharply to just over £60,000. There was a slight dip. (At this point)

  1. There was a slight rise to just under £60,000. The figure went down considerably. (Subsequently)

  1. Income fell significantly to £40,000. The number levelled off. (Next)

LESSON 8 – SPEAKING

SPEAKING PART 1 QUESTION TYPES (PART 1)

  1. Description questions

Look at the example question: “Tell me about your hometown.”

This seems like a simple question. Candidates must remember that the examiner is NOT asking this question because he or she wants to know something about your hometown.

Remember: The examiner is not interested in you, your life or anything you say. The examiner is doing a job. The job is to award a score for your spoken English in relation to the marking system.

So again we can see that content becomes irrelevant. The examiner is actually asking the following question: “Show me your ability to describe something (a place) and give me some town or city vocabulary.”

Most candidates will probably be asked at least one description question. This question is often one of the first questions in Part 1.

  1. Strategy: divide into 2 or 3 parts
  2. Structure: point 1 + point 2 + point 3
  3. Sample question: "Tell me something about your hometown."

  1. Useful language:

Starting-off (redundant language): ok, then, actually, alright, well, you know,

Point 1

  • I'd like to begin by saying ...
  • The first thing I'd like to mention is ...
  • The main thing you need to know is ...

Point 2

  • On top of that, I can also add that ...
  • Another interesting point ...
  • Not only that but …. is also exceedingly ....

Point 3 (if needed)

  • Finally, I'd also like to mention ........
  • And, I shouldn't forget to mention that …
  • I guess I could also say that (it's) sort of …

Activity 1: Work in pairs. Answer the questions below:

  • What does your neighborhood look like?
  • What does your city/town look like?
  • Describe a city you would like to visit?
  • Describe a country you would like to visit?

Guided practice: What does your neighborhood look like?

  • Point 1:

Residential area- a mix of houses and apartment buildings

  • Point 2:

Commercial facilities- shopping center, supermarket, pharmacy, convenience stores

  • Point 3:

Transportation and infrastructure- well-connected

Sample answer: Well, I live in the center of Hanoi and I really like my neighborhood. I'd like to begin by saying that it is primarily a residential area with a mix of houses and apartment

buildings. In addition to being a residential area, my neighborhood also has various commercial facilities like a shopping center nearby, a supermarket, a pharmacy, and a few convenience stores. This is convenient for residents as they can easily access daily necessities without having to travel long distances. Finally, I'd also like to mention that my neighborhood is well-connected in terms of transportation and infrastructure. There is a bus stop just a short walk away from my residence, providing easy access to public transportation.

residential area: khu dân cư

a mix of sth: pha trộn giữa

commercial facilities: các tiện nghi thương mại daily necessities: nhu yếu phẩm hàng ngày well-connected (adj): kết nối tốt

  1. "Types of" questions

  1. Strategy: divide into 2 or 3 parts
  2. Structure: general statement + type 1 + type 2
  3. Sample questions: "Tell me about the different types of public transportation in your city."

  1. Useful language

Rephrasing types: kinds, sorts, variety, range of, array

Useful phrases to start (General statement)

  • There's quite a mixed variety of ...
  • There's a fairly wide range of ...
  • There's quite a diverse mixture of ...

Type 1

  • I think the most common one is...
  • The main one is....
  • The first one that comes to mind is...

Type 2

  • In addition, X … is also extremely popular
  • Another kind is ...
  • Not only that, but X … is also exceedingly .....

Type 3 (if needed)

  • And I shouldn't forget to mention that...
  • I guess I could also say that...
  • Finally, I'd also like to mention...

Activity 2: Work in pairs. Answer the questions.

  • What kinds of restaurants are popular in your country?
  • What types of shops can be found in your local area?
  • What types of things do people collect in your country?
  • What sorts of TV programs are popular in your hometown?

Guided practice: What kinds of restaurants are popular in your country?

  • Point 1:

Traditional cuisine restaurants- authentic dishes

  • Point 2:

International cuisine restaurants- provide an opportunity for people to explore different flavors

  • Point 3:

Fast food chains and casual dining- offer quick and convenient options

Sample answer: Well, you know there's quite a mixed variety of restaurants in my country. I think the most common one is traditional cuisine restaurants because they specialize in serving authentic dishes that are deeply rooted in our cultural heritage. In addition, international cuisine restaurants are also extremely popular as they provide an opportunity for people to explore different flavors and culinary traditions from around the world. And I shouldn't forget

to mention that fast food chains and casual dining restaurants have also become increasingly popular in my country thanks to their quick and convenient options for people on the go or looking for a relaxed dining experience.

be deeply rooted in: ăn sâu vào…

cultural heritage: di sản văn hoá

casual dining restaurants: nhà hàng bình dân

on the go (idiom): rất bận rộn

  1. Liking/disliking questions

  1. Strategy: general to specific
  2. Structure: general statement + more precise statement + reason
  3. Sample answer: "What kind of animals do you like?"

  1. Useful language Rephrasing "liking"

  • I'm pretty fond of ...
  • I'm really keen on ...
  • I'm a big fan of ...
  • I'm extremely passionate about ...

Rephrasing "Disliking"

  • I really can't stand ...
  • I'm not really fond of ...
  • I'm not much of a fan of ...
  • ... simply gets on my nerves.

General statement

  • Well, in general, I would say ...
  • Generally speaking ...
  • Overall, I think that ...

More precise statement

  • In particular, …
  • Specifically, …
  • To be more precise ...

Reason

  • And I guess this is probably because ...
  • I think this is due to the fact that ...
  • The reason for this is because ...

Activity 3: Work in pairs. Answer the questions.

  • What do you like about your hometown?
  • Where do you like to shop in your hometown?
  • What types of vehicles do you use the most?
  • What types of free time activities do people in your hometown like?
  • Is there anything you don't like about your hometown?
  • Is there any local food in your hometown that you don't like?
  • What type of weather in your country do you dislike?
  • What type of movies do young people in your country dislike?

Guided practice: What do you like about your hometown?

  • General statement:

facilities

  • More precise statement

recreational facilities

  • Reason:

cater to diverse interests

Sample answer: Well, in general, I would say that there are many things I appreciate about my hometown, but one aspect that stands out to me is the excellent range of facilities it offers. In particular, I'm really keen on the abundance of recreational facilities available for residents and

visitors alike. The reason behind my admiration for the range of facilities is that they cater to diverse interests and provide ample opportunities for leisure and entertainment.

stand out: nổi bật abundance (n): sự phong phú ample (adj): phong phú

LESSON 8 – WRITING BAR CHART

  1. Understanding bar charts

Bar chart - Column chart showing the variation of the object (based on a certain unit). This type of article often requires analyzing characteristics, data, comparison, and predicting trends of the subject. There are two types: Bar chart with change over time (dynamic) and no change over time (static) with different characteristics and methods.

A dynamic chart shows change over time, we have a progression of change happening throughout the time period.

A static chart shows a snapshot of a moment in time.

Each type requires a different approach and, of course, a different vocabulary.

  1. How to write

  1. Writing an introduction

Similar to the Line Graph task, the introduction in the Bar Chart task also aims to paraphrase the prompt. Whether it's a Dynamic or Static task, the introduction will still follow the same writing style.

For example: The graph shows data about the average Saturday sales of two bakeries in London in 2010.

The graph

shows

about the average Saturday sales of two

bakeries

in London

in 2010

The bar graph

illustrates

the average Saturday sales of two bakeries

in London

in the year 2010

Introduction: The bar graph illustrates the average Saturday sales of two bakeries in London in the year 2010.

Remember: You don't necessarily have to paraphrase every single word in the prompt to create a standard introduction.

  1. Static bar chart

  1. Writing an overview

The graph shows data about the average Saturday sales of two bakeries in London in 2010.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

PRACTICE 1

Decide whether these statements about the graph are true (T) or false (F). Correct the false ones.

  1. On a typical Saturday, Bernie's Buns is generally busier than Lovely Loaves.
  2. Doughnuts are by far the most popular item among customers in both stores.
  3. The second-best selling item in Bernie's Buns is cookies.
  4. Fresh loaves are the least popular snack overall.
  5. Toasted sandwiches are as popular as cookies.
  6. Lovely Loaves sells slightly more salads than Bernie's Buns.

When dealing with a static bar chart, the overview should mention items that have the highest or lowest values.

Remember to use superlative structures in your overview. You may write one sentence for the highest and one sentence for the lowest value.

Example: Overall, doughnuts are by far the most popular item among customers in both stores, while the least popular item is toasted sandwiches.

PRACTICE 2

Write an overview for the charts below.

The chart below shows the death number in Someland in 1990.

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

  1. Key language for making comparisons

In Task 1, you need to compare accurately the information presented in the charts in a variety of different ways. In this lesson, you will review and develop a variety of useful ways of doing this.

One of the ways is to use comparative and superlative.

PRACTICE 3

Write these adjectives in their comparative and superlative forms in the correct columns of the table below.

Comparative

Superlative

-er

more/less

the + adjective +

-est/iest

the most/the least +

adjective

busier

more comfortable

the busiest

the most comfortable

PRACTICE 4

Write sentences about these pairs using comparatives. Share ideas with a partner.

Example: The countryside is quieter than the city.

  • the city / the countryside

learning grammar / learning vocabulary

  • cricket / football
  • New York / Paris
  • travelling business class / travelling economy class
  • a plane / a bicycle

Before comparatives, you can use words to indicate if the difference is large or small: A Rolls Royce is much more expensive than a Ford.

PRACTICE 5

Say whether these words relate to small differences or big differences.

much

a lot

slightly

a bit

considerably

a little

far

Small differences

Big differences

PRACTICE 6

Finish each of these sentence starters with a comparative and your own idea. Compare with a partner.

  1. Travelling by train is slightly...
  2. A night in a hotel costs much more...
  3. London is considerably...

Superlatives are also a useful way to rank and order the information you find in Task 1 graphs.

PRACTICE 7

Complete these sentences using the information in the chart below.

  1. The most expensive coffee is in        , at £2.90.
  2. The second most expensive is in ........................., where it costs ………… .
  3. Coffee in ........................ is the third m..................., at ...................................
  4. The next ........................ coffee is ..................................
  5. The least ..................................

  1. Static bar charts with lots of columns

The chart below shows the amount spent on six consumer goods in four European countries.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

The following bar chart has a total of 24 bars. It's impossible to describe 24 pieces of information in only 20 minutes, so you need to select.

A simple rule is to select at least one key thing about each country. The key thing may be the highest / lowest spending on all 6 products, the highest for some categories but the lowest for others,…

PRACTICE 8

Find one key thing about each country

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

  1. Dynamic bar chart

The chart below shows the total number of minutes (in billions) of telephone calls in the UK, divided into three categories, from 1995- 2002.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

STEP 1: Write an introduction

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 2: Write an overview

For a dynamic bar chart overview, you should mention 2 things. First, you should refer to the items with the highest and / or lowest values (like in a static bar chart). The second thing is the trend of items (upward / downward trend- refer to lesson 7 about how to write an overview for a line graph)

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 3: Compare the noticeable features in the first year (like what you do when describing a static bar chart)

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 4: Describe the movements in the remaining years, focus on the last year of the period (like what you do when describing a line graph)

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

LESSON 9 – SPEAKING SPEAKING PART 1 QUESTION TYPES (PART 2)

  1. Habit questions

a .Strategy: Depends

  1. Structure: Depends + preference 1 + preference 2
  2. Sample questions: “What do you usually do at the weekend?”

  1. Useful language Depends

  • Well, it is contingent upon …
  • I think it depends, really …
  • Well, to be honest, I would have to say that it really depends …

Preference 1

  • If I'm...
  • I prefer to...
  • Usually, I prefer...
  • Sometimes, I prefer to...

Preference 2

  • But, if I... I would rather...
  • Although, sometimes I would rather...
  • However, if I have...

Activity 4: Work in pairs. Answer the questions.

  • How often do you go to the cinema?
  • Where do you usually go shopping?
  • When do you usually read?
  • How often do you play sports?
  • How often do you eat in restaurants?

Guided practice: How often do you go to the cinema?

  • Preference 1:

During term time- once every few months or when there is a favorite movie

  • Preference 2:

During school holidays- more frequently

Sample answer: Well, it is contingent upon periods in a year. During term time, when I have academic commitments and a more structured routine, I tend to go to the cinema less frequently. I prioritize my studies and other responsibilities, so I might only go to the cinema once every few months or when there is a movie I'm particularly excited about. But, during school holidays, when I have more free time and fewer academic obligations, I often find myself going to the cinema more frequently. With the break from school, I have the opportunity to catch up on the latest movies and enjoy the cinematic experience.

academic commitments / obligations: các trách nhiệm liên quan tới học tập

latest movie: phim mới ra rạp

cinematic experience: trải nghiệm điện ảnh

  1. Yes/No questions

  1. Strategy: Depends
  2. Structure: Depends + option 1 + option 2
  3. Sample question: “Do you eat healthy food?”

  1. Useful language (See in 4.d)

Activity 5: Work in pairs. Answer the questions.

  • Do you like the weather in your country?
  • Do you enjoy eating food from other countries?
  • Do you enjoy your work/studies?
  • Do you enjoy going shopping?
  • Do you like to get up early?
  • Do you play or watch any sports?

Guided practice: Do you like the weather in your country?

  • Option 1:

hot- yes

  • Option 2:

rainy- no

Sample answer: Well, to be honest, I would have to say that it really depends on the specific conditions. If it is the hot season, I generally enjoy the weather in my country. The warm temperatures and sunny days create a vibrant and energetic atmosphere. On the other hand, when it comes to rainy weather, my opinion might lean towards the negative side. I find that heavy rain and constant gloominess can dampen my mood and limit outdoor activities.

vibrant (adj): sôi động energetic (adj): năng động gloominess (n): sự ảm đạm

dampen the mood: làm giảm sự phấn chấn, vui vẻ

  1. “Would” questions

  1. Strategy: Avoidance
  2. Structure: Avoid + answer the question (Note that this is just an imaginary situation so you may need to use the second conditional to express your idea)
  3. Sample question: “Would you like to move to another city?”

  1. Useful language Avoidance

  • Well, quite honestly I don't think I've ever thought about that, but I guess...
  • Actually, this isn't something that I've ever considered, but in short...
  • I'm not really sure how to put this, but I suppose generally speaking...

Answer the question (if you agree with the question, use the second conditional)

Activity 6: Work in pairs. Answer the questions.

  • Would you like to change your job?
  • Would you like to live near the sea?
  • Would you like to learn another foreign language?
  • Would you like to be in a film?

Guided practice: Would you like to change your job?

  • Avoidance:

Actually, this isn't something that I've ever considered …

  • Answer:

No, appreciate job stability and security …

Sample answer: Actually, this isn't something that I've ever considered, but in short I suppose I would not consider changing my job. I appreciate the stability and security that my current job provides. It offers a sense of financial stability and benefits that are important for my personal and professional well-being.

stability (n): sự ổn định

security (n): sự an toàn

well-being (n): trạng thái an toàn, thoải mái, hạnh phúc

LESSON 9 – WRITING PIE CHART

  1. Understanding static pie charts

Pie Chart is a round chart, broken down into sections with different colors or symbols for the subjects being compared. In this chart, each section will be represented by a metric (usually as a percentage) for a specific item.

This is a chart used to compare the differences between subjects at the same or different times. Pie charts are divided into two types:

  • Dynamic chart: Changing over time, each chart presents information for a year/month and often has multiple charts.

  • Static chart: A chart depicting a single subject (country/city/gender), with no comparison of different timelines between charts and only a single pie chart.

  1. How to write
  1. Useful languages
  1. Comparative structures

In the previous lesson, we learned two effective ways to compare, that is, comparative and superlative. Another important way to write about comparatives is to use the structure:

'x is not as + adjective + as y'.

Coffee in France is not as expensive as in the UK.

Becoming confident using this structure will make your writing more flexible.

PRACTICE 1

Use the structure above to rewrite this sentence.

The Fratton Road library was less busy than the one in Commercial Road in March.

PRACTICE 2

Rewrite the comparative sentences below using not as + adjective (from the box) + as.

  1. Monster Hits Records sold 230,000 CDs in 1990, whereas Crooners plc sold 225,000.

  1. A hundred couples chose the name James in 2000, while just 20 couples opted for the name Peter.

  1. It costs an average of £95 to spend a night in a hotel in Paris, as opposed to over £150 in Zurich.

  1. The temperature in Rawai Island was much lower than in Phuket, at 15 degrees and 25 degrees respectively.

PRACTICE 3

Look at these phrases and decide whether they express a big difference or a small one.

  1. X is/was nowhere near as expensive as Y. big difference
  2. X is/was not quite as expensive as Y.         
  3. X is/was not nearly as expensive as Y.         
  4. X is/was almost as expensive as Y.         

PRACTICE 4

Rewrite the sentences in Practice 3 using one of the four phrases from Practice 4 to express whether there is a small or large difference.

Example: Crooners plc was not quite as successful as Monster Hits Records in 1990, selling 225,000 CDS compared to 230,000.

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

  1. Describing percentages

Often in Task 1, you will need to write about percentages. It is important to be able to express these in different ways.

 𝑛𝑢𝑚𝑒𝑟𝑎𝑡𝑜𝑟   => [cardinal number- ordinal number]

If the numerator is bigger than 1, add “-s” to the denominator Example:

 1  = one-third

 2  = two-thirds

PRACTICE 5

Match these percentages (a-g) to the fractions (1-7).

  1. 50%        1. two-thirds

  1. 25%        2. half
  2. 75%        3. a/one quarter
  3. 33.3%        4. two-fifths
  4. 40%        5. three-quarters
  5. 10%        6. a/one third
  6. 66.6%        7. a/one tenth

PRACTICE 6

Write a suitable percentage for each of these descriptions.

  1. just over three-quarters 76%
  2. Nearly a third of girls said ...
  3. Just under a quarter of people asked said ...
  4. around a third of all passengers
  5. almost half of students
  6. Approximately two-thirds of parents said ...

PRACTICE 7

Write these percentages in words and add an idea to create a sentence. Use the subject in brackets to help you.

  1. 32% (smokers)

Just under a third of all smokers said they smoked fewer than 20 cigarettes a day.

  1. 52% (teenagers)

  1. 74% (household appliances)

PRACTICE 8

Look at these four different ways for writing about key percentages. 10%        a tenth of one in ten / one out of ten / one out of every ten Rewrite these key percentages using one of the four ways above.

  1. 20%         
  2. 25%         
  3. 50%         

  1. Linking devices

PRACTICE 9

These sentences contain four useful linking devices. Find and underline them. The first one has been done for you.

  1. a. Monster Hits Records sold 230,000 CDs in 1990, while Crooners plc sold 225,000.

b. Monster Hits Records sold 230,000 CDs in 1990, as opposed to Crooners plc, who sold 225.000.

  1. a. A hundred couples chose the name James in 2000, whereas just 20 couples opted for the name Peter.

b. A hundred couples chose the name James in 2000, compared to 20 who opted for the name

Peter.

Notice that:

Whereas and while are followed by 'subject + verb', e.g. While Crooners plc sold....

Compared to and as opposed to are followed by 'subject + relative clause', e.g.        as opposed to

Crooners plc who sold ...

PRACTICE 10

Correct the mistakes in these sentences.

  1. Just 10% of first-time buyers said they needed a garage, as opposed to 30% said a large kitchen was necessary.
  2. Just 10% of first-time buyers said they needed a garage, whereas 30% who said a large kitchen was necessary.

PRACTICE 11

Complete these sentences with a suitable linking device and idea. Compare your answers with a partner.

  1. Five hundred people owned a dog, while ...
  2. A meal at Rosie's costs £20, as opposed to...
  3. Fifteen percent of people aged between 18 and 30 said they visited Barcelona for the nightlife, compared to ...
  4. The majority of doctors said they found their jobs satisfying, whereas ...

  1. Writing an introduction for pie chart

Similar to the Bar Graph task, the introduction in the Pie Chart task also aims to paraphrase the prompt. Whether it's a Dynamic or Static task, the introduction will still follow the same writing style.

For example: The pie charts below show the comparison of different kinds of energy production in France in two years.

The pie

charts below

show

the comparison of different

kinds of energy production

in France

in two years

The pie graphs

compare

the proportion of energy produced by different

sources

in France

in 1995 and 2005

Introduction: The pie graphs compare the proportion of energy produced by different sources in France in 1995 and 2005

  1. Static pie chart

  1. Writing an overview

In a static Pie Chart, you won't see any trend changes or special points. Let's conduct a size analysis of the items based on the respective sizes of the section. Then you should state the biggest and smallest fractions of the charts.

For example, when analyzing the topic according to the above section, you will identify typical information such as:

  • Highest spending: Social security
  • Lowest spending: Transport

Overall, the UAE government’s maximum spending went into social security while the least amount was spent on transport.

PRACTICE 12

Write an overview for the chart below.

The pie charts below compare water usage in San Diego, California and the rest of the world.

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

  1. Practice: Describing a static pie chart

The pie charts below show the average household expenditures in Japan and Malaysia in the year 2010.

Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

PRACTICE 13

Read this sample answer. Find out how details in the 2 body paragraph are selected and grouped

The bar charts illustrate data regarding the average spending patterns of households in Japan and Malaysia across five different categories of goods and services in the year 2010.

Overall, Japanese households allocated the highest portion of their expenditure towards other goods and services, whereas housing accounted for the largest proportion of spending among Malaysian households. Moreover, both countries allocated the least amount of expenditure towards health-care.

Specifically, the percentage of expenditure on housing in Japan was 21%, which was 13% lower compared to that of Malaysian households. Japan's expenditure on food accounted for 24% of their total expenditure, while Malaysia's figure was slightly higher at 27%. Regarding spending on other goods and services, Japan allocated 29% of its total expenditure, whereas Malaysia's proportion was slightly smaller, at 26%.

In terms of transport expenses, Japan dedicated one-fifth of their total expenditure, while Malaysia's share was significantly lower, constituting just one-tenth. Additionally, 6% of Japanese household expenditure was directed towards health-care, whereas the figure for Malaysia was half of that amount.

Body 1:

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

Body 2:

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

  1. Dynamic pie chart

  1. Writing an overview

With this type of lesson, you will be given 2 or more charts to show the change of values over time. This type of lesson is a bit complicated when you not only have to compare items but also analyze their changes over time.

The overview section in a dynamic pie chart will focus on highlighting two factors:

  • The highest/lowest values throughout the period
  • Point out values that are trending up or down.

PRACTICE 14

Write an overview for the chart below.

The given pie charts compare the expenses in 7 different categories in 1966 and 1996 by American Citizens.

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

  1. Selecting and grouping data

To select and group information in the 2 body paragraphs, you can follow these steps:

  • First, compare fragments in the first years like what you do in a static pie chart
  • Then, describe the movement of these fragments. You may draw arrows going up, down, or symbols indicating no change in the chart to follow easily. For charts with more than 2 graphs representing more than 2 years, you don't necessarily have to show year-over-year increases and decreases. However, you need to focus on the final year's data. This is really similar to what you do in a line graph.

PRACTICE 15

Write some sentence to describe the movement of categories in the charts below

Example: In 1992, the percentage of adult fiction sold increased slightly by 5%, then continued its upward trend more significantly to 45% by 2012

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

LESSON 10 – SPEAKING

IELTS SPEAKING PART 2 – DESCRIBE A PERSON
