  1. Introduction to IELTS Speaking part 2 Part 2: Individual long turn

Length: 3–4 minutes

After Part 1, the examiner will give you a topic and ask you to talk about it for one to two minutes.

The topic will be handed to you on a card and you will also be given a piece of paper and a pencil for making notes. On the card, you will see the speaking prompt and some points you can cover in your talk relating to this.

You will have exactly one minute to prepare and make notes before you speak. Here is a sample Part 2 task:

Describe a beautiful place to visit in your city. You should say:

  • where it is
  • how to get there
  • what there is to do when you are there and explain why you recommend this place.

After the one-minute preparation, you will be asked to begin and the examiner will listen to you for two minutes. They may ask you a couple of follow-up questions when the time is up before going on to the next section.

Tips for doing well in Part 2:

  • Take notes! The initial thoughts you note down will help you remember what you have to say.
  • Try to structure your talk with a simple beginning, middle and end.

You can use key words from the prompt to form an introductory sentence:

For example, take the words “beautiful place” “visit” and “city” from the above prompt and begin your talk with: “I would like to talk to you today about an area of my city that everyone should go see because its beauty is outstanding.”

Then, use the three bullet points to help you organise the middle of your talk and conclude by explaining why this is the place you most recommend.

  • Extend each part of your answer with some details. You have two minutes to fill and you need show that you can enlarge on a topic and use a range of expressions, grammatical structures and vocabulary.
  • Use the full two minutes. Practise talking in front of a mirror on a subject for two minutes so you get a sense of the timing.

  1. Sample questions

In this lesson, you will learn how to give a monologue about a person. Typical IELTS Part Two questions about a person include:

  1. Talk about a good cook.
  2. Talk about a famous person you'd like to meet.
  3. Talk about an animal you find interesting.
  4. Talk about a person who looked after you as a child.
  5. Talk about a teacher you know.
  6. Talk about a neighbour you have or have had.
  7. Talk about a person you enjoy spending time with.
  8. Talk about one of your friends.
  9. Talk about an old person you know who lives near you.
  10. Talk about a person you know who is beautiful or handsome.
  11. Talk about a person who helps to protect the environment.

  1. Structure of an answer

The prompts of each cue card can vary, but to give a good monologue about a person, here are some basic stages you can follow:

Stage 1: Say who they are and how you know them.

Stage 2: Say what they are like and what they do.

Stage 3: Say what they have achieved and how they have influenced you.

Stage 4: Say why they are special and how you feel about them. Here is an example cue card

  1. Useful language

  1. Stage 1

For stage 1 of a person monologue, you may say who they are and how you know them.

When giving a monologue about a person, it's always a great idea to say something about the person's relationship to you, their occupation, or social position.

Here are some more examples:

Relatives

Occupations

Relationship/Social Position

great-grandfather

surgeon

celebrity

grandparents

accountant

star

aunt

architect

politician

uncle

civil servant

TV presenter

cousin

plumber

sports personality

brother-in-law

electrician

friend of the family

mother-in-law

butcher

childhood friend

stepfather

self-employed

(ex-)boyfriend/(ex-)girlfriend

nephew

waiter/waitress

distant relation

Examples

I would like to talk about my nephew, who is a plumber like me.

I really admire Daniel Craig, who is an excellent actor and has recently become a huge movie star.

My grandparents were both surgeons during the war.

Activity 1: Write the words and phrases below in the correct spaces.

  1. Yao Ming is probably the most popular         in China.
  2. I never speak to my         ; he hurt me too much when our relationship ended.
  3. It's a great shame that Chris Bailey, who was a         of mine, passed away a few years ago.
  4. My family all trust and like Richard Haward. We've known him so long and he always comes to our family events – he's a true         
  5. I don't like to watch the show “I Love Movies” because I can't stand the

         who hosts the programme.

  1. My schoolmate Saskia Clarke has become something of a         after competing in the 2008 Olympics.

Activity 2: Here is a cue card in IELTS Speaking Part 2

Prepare the first prompt and tell your partner about it.

  1. Stage 2

For stage 2 of a person monologue, you should say what they are like and what they do.

When giving a monologue about a person, it's very important to accurately use adjectives of personality to describe what the person is / was like.

Look at some more examples of useful adjectives of personality:

Funny

Shy

Confident

Angry

Happy

Humorous

Reserved

Ambitious

Aggressive

Charming

Witty

Introverted

Self-confident

Bad-tempered

Cheerful

Hysterical

Quiet

Self-assured

Moody

Vivacious

Hilarious

Sensitive

Extroverted

Irritate

Lively

Amusing

Conservative

Adventurous

Short-fused

Timid

Arrogant

Abrupt

Helpful

Honest

Kind

Intelligent

Stupid

Considerate

Straightforward

Gentle

Clever

Immature

Supportive

Frank

Calm

Bright

Silly

Sympathetic

Reliable

Generous

Mature

Dumb

Genuine

Loving

Talented

Dim

Sincere

Thoughtful

Open-minded

Daft

Altruistic

Wise

Foolish

Examples:

He is a very extroverted person, and really likes to be the centre of attention.

She seems like a very vivacious and self-assured woman, though she's perhaps quite abrupt if you make her angry.

My girlfriend really has two sides to her personality; when she's happy she can be open-minded, thoughtful and really supportive, but when she's in a bad mood she can be really irritable and selfish.

Activity 3: Write the words below in the correct spaces.

bright

charming

ambitious

generous

supportive

reserved

moody

immature

humorous

frank

  1. My colleague is really         ,she is often irritable and angry - sometimes I'm too scared to speak to her!
  2. I always have lots of ideas at work, but whenever I tell my manager he never listens and nothing changes – I wish my boss was more         .
  3. My nephew is almost 25, but he still plays computer games and doesn't think about the future. He's far too         .
  4. Politicians are rarely         with the public; usually they hide the truth or just tell people a part of the truth.
  5. Many women really like Brad Pitt not only because he is handsome but because he seems really         .
  6. Bill Gates is obviously an extremely         man; otherwise he wouldn't have been so successful.
  7. One thing I really appreciated about my grandparents was that they were so

        - they gave me whatever I needed and didn't really care about money.

  1. I think my uncle is still not married because he is extremely         . He doesn't like to say much when other people are present and his views are quite traditional.
  2. My doctor is fantastic – even though her patients are really nervous about seeing the doctor or going to the hospital, she is so         that she can make them laugh and relax straight away.
  3. Although David Beckham is a great football player, he isn't very         - don't ask him any complicated maths questions!

Notice the way the speaker gives small comments on the person they want to describe. Instead of just listing down characteristics like “She is funny, beautiful,…”, you should explain your comment in detail. You may add the reasons why you say she is beautiful, or an example for her humor.

For example: Sarah is really funny. Every time she tells a joke, everyone in the room bursts into laughter.

Activity 4: Prepare the second prompt in Activity 2 and tell your partner about it.

  1. Stage 3

For stage 3 of a person monologue, you should say what they have achieved and how they have influenced you.

When talking about people that are important to you, or who you admire, here are some phrases that you can use.

Look at the following phrases of achievements:

through sheer hard work

to struggle for/to do something

Working hard

to strive for something to fight for something

to have the determination to do something

to stand up for something/somebody

to show perseverance

Examples:

She struggled to get where she is now – she deserves to be so famous! He fought for everything he has achieved – I admire him greatly!

Success

to have the will to succeed to have a desire for success

to climb the ladder of success

to have a long and brilliant career to earn the respect of somebody to get a lucky break

Examples:

Slowly but surely, she climbed the ladder of success and finally reached the top position.

He suffered many hardships but nevertheless had a long and brilliant career.

Talent

to have a gift for doing something

to have an outstanding talent for doing something

to develop his/her talent for doing something/as a(n)...

Examples:

My brother-in-law has really developed his talent as an actor; in recent years he has often appeared in professional plays.

Activity 5: Write the phrases below in the correct spaces.

  1. The problem with Ben is that he doesn't         - he just gives up as soon as he meets a problem.
  2. I admire Dr. Atkinson, who was my Science professor, because she was from an extremely poor family and it was         that she became an expert in her field.
  3. My brother truly         cooking; everything he tries tastes fantastic!
  4. Most people are impressed with Nelson Mandela's achievements. He showed determination         freedom, equality and human rights.
  5. In the future, I hope to find a well-paid job in an international company so that I can

        of my parents.

Activity 6: Prepare the third prompt in Activity 2 and tell your partner about it.

  1. Stage 4

For stage 4 of a person monologue, you should say why they are special and how you feel about them.

  • When giving a monologue about a person, you should use expressions of admiration to say why the person is special, or why you admire them.

Here are some expressions of admiration:

respect

appreciate

look up to

admire

think highly of

feel proud of

truly hold in high

regard

consider to be the

best

Everyone respects wise and peaceful leaders such as Mahatma Gandhi. My niece really appreciates what my parents did for her.

I look up to her because she is good-natured.

I will always admire him for his extraordinary ability.

His colleagues all think highly of my stepbrother and his work. I feel proud of my mother’s achievements.

I truly hold in high regard people such as President Obama.

Many movie enthusiasts consider him to be the best actor of his generation.

  • When we talk about people who are special or important to us, we often express the feeling that we want to be the same as them in some way.

Here are some ways to say “I hope.        ”

I hope I am as + adjective + as + person

I hope I will be as + adjective + as + person

Examples:

I hope I am as successful as Bill Gates.

I hope I will be as successful as Bill Gates.

I hope I am as happy as my next-door neighbor when I am old.

I hope I will be as kind a teacher as Mrs. Capp.

I would love to be like my mother.

I would like to be as well-respected as my father.

I want to be like my neighbor Doris when I’m older.

  • Here are some more expressions for describing role models:

A fine example

A hero

A pop icon

A charismatic leader

An idol

A mentor

A visionary

A sex symbol

Example:

John Lennon became a big pop icon. Hen was all over the media. Ringo was his mentor for the first year he lived away from home.

Charles Manson, who was imprisoned for the murder of Sharon Tate, was a crazy

charismatic leader during the 1960s.

Some people say that the Beatles were not only a talented rock band, but they were

visionaries for their generation.

Activity 7: Write the phrases below in the correct spaces.

A fine

example

A hero

A pop icon

A charismatic leader

An idol

  1. Nelson Mandela is widely regarded as         of resilience and forgiveness.
  2. Martin Luther King Jr. is remembered as         of the civil rights movement.
  3. Many young athletes see Serena Williams as         and inspiration.
  4. Mahatma Gandhi is celebrated as         of non-violent resistance.
  5. Maya Angelou's powerful words make her         for aspiring writers.

Activity 8: Prepare the final prompt in Activity 2 and tell your partner about it.

Activity 9: Using the answer order above, put the following extracts from a model answer into the correct order.

  1. Grandma Lily is my maternal grandmother, and she has been a pillar of love and support since the day I was born. Growing up, I spent a considerable amount of time with her, especially during school vacations. She was always there to care for me, nurture me, and offer guidance whenever I needed it. What sets Grandma Lily apart is her warm and nurturing nature. She has a gentle and caring personality that instantly puts me at ease. She exudes kindness and radiates love, making everyone around her feel cherished. Her days were filled with tasks that revolved around ensuring my well-being. From cooking my favorite meals to helping me with my homework, she spared no effort in providing a loving and nurturing environment.

  1. When I think about a person who played a significant role in looking after me during my childhood, my mind immediately goes to my grandmother, whom I affectionately call Grandma Lily. I have a deep connection with her, and her presence in my life has left an indelible mark on me. Grandma Lily is my maternal grandmother, and she has been a pillar of love and support since the day I was born. Growing up, I spent a considerable amount of time with her, especially during school vacations. She was always there to care for me, nurture me, and offer guidance whenever I needed it.

  1. To me, Grandma Lily is an extraordinary person who is incredibly special. The love and care she showered upon me during my formative years have created a bond that is unbreakable. She has taught me the importance of unconditional love, empathy, and the

power of a nurturing presence. Whenever I think of her, my heart fills with gratitude and a deep sense of affection.

  1. While Grandma Lily may not have achieved fame or recognition in the traditional sense, her accomplishments lie in the immeasurable impact she has had on my life. She has been a constant source of encouragement, empowering me to believe in myself and pursue my dreams. Her unwavering support has given me the confidence to overcome challenges and strive for excellence.

  1. Exam practice PART 1

  1. What kind of people do you like to make friends with?
  2. What do you think makes good friends?
  3. Do you think you are a good friend for others?
  4. Do you have any far friends? How close are you to them? Why are they close to you?
  5. Have you ever contacted your friends from primary school?
  6. How important childhood friends are?

PART 2

LESSON 10 – WRITING TABLE

  1. Understanding static and dynamic tables

Table is one of the chart types in IELTS. This chart type will give a table with a series of figures representing the same topic but different in time, place, and specific object. The test often asks candidates to summarize key information by selecting and reporting on features and comparing data with each other. The requirements for the assignment usually take the form of the following:

“Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, making comparisons where relevant”

The Table format consists of two main types of data tables and the way to write Writing Task 1 in Table form will not be too different in each form:

  • Dynamic table: This type is quite similar to the line and dynamic bar chart because it is necessary to show the trend of data changes over the research period. At the same time, it is still necessary to point out salient metrics such as fast/slow-growing subjects, and compare them with each other.

  • Static table: This type does not need to show the changing trend of the data, but only compares them with each other and gives outstanding indicators such as: highest score, and lowest score.

  1. Using advanced comparatives

A further way to increase your range of language for describing comparatives is to use:

'not + verb + as + noun phrase + as'.

Crooners plc did not sell as many CDs as Monster Hits Records in 1990, with 225,000 compared to 230,000.

Coffee in France does not cost as much as in the UK, at £2 and £2.90 respectively.

PRACTICE 1

Look at the table below and complete these sentences with 'not + (verb) + as + noun phrase

+ as'. Be careful, one sentence is different.

  1. Japan did not        Ethiopia, taking home nine compared to Ethiopia's ten.
  2. The USA won 48 gold medals, but this was nowhere near        China won.
  3. The USA was        China, winning 48 medals compared to 62.
  4. Australia did not        the French athletes, taking home 21 compared

to France’s 33.

  1. Ranking information

In order to write a good Task 1 answer, you will need a wide range of language to help you to rank and order information given in charts and tables.

  • In first / second / last place is / was....
  • Top / Bottom of the list was.....
  • The number one [item] is / was...
  • was ranked second with ...
  • First / Last on the list was...
  • headed the list with...
  • Ranked in third place was...
  • The most / second most / next most / least popular [item] is / was...
  • Next came...
  • This was followed by ...

PRACTICE 2

Look at the table below. How could you rank these activities, starting with sport / fitness activities? Discuss with a partner and note some useful language.

Example: Sport was the most popular leisure activity.

  1. How to write

  1. Writing an introduction for Table

Similar to the Pie Graph task, the introduction in the Table task also aims to paraphrase the prompt. Whether it's a Dynamic or Static task, the introduction will still follow the same writing style.

For example: The table below gives information on consumer spending on different items in five different countries in 2002.

The table

below

gives

information        on        consumer

spending on different items

in        five        different

countries

in 2002

The table

shows

percentages of consumer expenditure for three categories  of  products and

services

in five nations

in the year 2002

Introduction: The table shows percentages of consumer expenditure for three categories of products and services in five nations in the year 2002.

  1. Static tables

The table below gives information about the underground railway systems in six cities.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

STEP 1: Write an introduction

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 2: Write an overview

For the static table overview, you should refer to the items with the highest and/or lowest values. Try to compare whole categories (columns or rows) rather than individual 'cells' in the table. If you can't compare whole categories, compare the biggest and smallest number.

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

In your two 'details' paragraphs, never describe each category (column or row) separately. The examiner wants to see comparisons. Try to organize the numbers you highlighted into 2 groups -

one for each paragraph (e.g. highest numbers for all categories together, and lowest numbers together).

For example, in this case, we can group the 3 oldest networks in one paragraph and 3 newest networks in another paragraph. Then, we try to highlight the most noticeable feature (e.g. the largest system, the most used system,…)

STEP 3: Describe the first group with noticeable features

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 4: Describe the remaining group with noticeable features

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

  1. Dynamic tables

The table shows the percentage of mobile phone owners using various mobile phone features from 2006 to 2010.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

STEP 1: Write an introduction

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 2: Write an overview

For the dynamic table overview, you should mention 2 things. The first thing you should refer to is the items with the highest and/or lowest values (columns or rows). The second thing is the trend. You can also look for the biggest changes in numbers over the time period. Try to be flexible!

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

For the body of the dynamic tables, there are two ways to write it:

  • For articles where most of the categories share a common trend, we can write the way we're going to do it below – in the first body paragraph, we compare the noticeable features in the first year, and in the second body paragraph, we describe the trend of change, focusing on the last year's data
  • For articles where the items experience different trends, we will combine the lines with the same trend together to describe them. You will have a chance to try this approach in Exercise 2 Homework.

STEP 3: Compare the noticeable features in the first year

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 4: Describe the movements in the remaining years, focus on the last year of the period.

Stay focus on items with bigger changes.

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

LESSON 11 – SPEAKING

IELTS SPEAKING PART 2 – DESCRIBE AN OBJECT

  1. Sample questions

In this lesson, you will learn how to give a monologue about an object. Typical IELTS Part Two questions about an object include:

  1. Talk about something you'd like to buy.
  2. Talk about something you made yourself.
  3. Talk about an invention you know and like.
  4. Talk about a form of transport you use.
  5. Talk about something you enjoyed wearing.
  6. Talk about a piece of furniture in your house.
  7. Talk about a statue or work of art that you've seen.
  8. Talk about a photograph you have or have seen.
  9. Talk about a gift you were given. Here is a cue card in IELTS Speaking Part 2

  1. Structure of an answer

The prompts of each cue card can vary, but to give a good monologue about an object, here are some basic stages you can follow:

Stage 1: Say what it is and why you have it.

Stage 2: Say what its purpose is.

Stage 3: Evaluate it.

Stage 4: Say why it is important and how you feel about it.

  1. Useful language

  1. Stage 1

For stage 1 of an object monologue, you should say what it is and why you have it.

When giving a monologue about an object, as soon as you have said what the object is, you should then describe its appearance.

To describe an object well, it's important that you use the correct adjective order as below. (Generally, we don't use more than three adjectives together at the same time.)

Opinion

Size

Age

Shape

Colour

Origin

Material

beautiful

life-size

marble

a metre long

diamond-shaped

old

round

green

lovely

red

Vietnamese

Examples

  • A beautiful, almost life-size marble statue
  • The kite was about a metre long, diamond-shaped.
  • An old round green ball
  • A lovely red Vietnamese lantern

Some common Adjectives of Appearance:

Opinion

Size

Age

Shape

Colour

Origin

Material

handy

compact

ancient

round

blue

Chinese

cardboard

useful

life-size

old-fashioned

square

multi -

colored

American

cotton

useless

tiny

antique

rectangular

rainbow -

colored

western

golden

silly

little

worn

diamond -

shaped

black and

white

European

leather

cute

miniature

aged

oval

grey

African

plastic

terrible

enormous

brand-new

spherical

silver

mass -

produced

silk

attractive

huge

modern

curved

gold

factory -

produced

stone

ugly

gigantic

triangular

white with

blue stripes

home -

made

wooden

elegant

average-sized

new

cylindrical

black with

grey dots

hand-made

woolen

Activity 1: Use three adjectives to describe the objects mentioned below

  1. a mobile phone
  2. jeans
  3. a photo / picture
  4. a household appliance (microwave, fridge, washing machine,…)
  5. a sofa

Activity 2: Here is a cue card in IELTS Speaking Part 2

Prepare the first prompt and tell your partner about it.

  1. Stage 2

For stage 2 of an object monologue, you should say what its purpose is.

You should use expressions for uses in your monologue to explain how your object is used and/or why it is useful.

Expressions for Use

Examples

X + can help (people) +

(to) verb

The Internet can help people communicate across the world cheaply

and quickly.

X + is / are used + to

verb/for verb-ing

Microwaves ovens are used for cooking, baking, heating and

defrosting food and drinks.

X + is / are useful +for

verb-ing

The Internet blog I write is useful for developing my research and

writing skills.

X + is / are great + for

verb-ing

A pocket digital camera is great for taking quick photos while on

holiday.

X + provides

Online English classes provide an environment for students to

speak to real, live native English speakers.

X  +  provides  people

with

Cars        provide        ordinary        people        with        the        freedom  to  travel

independently anywhere at any time

X + is / are appreciated

because/for

The movie Lilies of the Field is appreciated because one of the

actors, Sidney Poiter, was the first black actor to win an Oscar.

X + is / are valued for

Egyptian mummies are valued for their historical significance.

X + is / are important

for

When I become a father, I want to buy a baby carry bag as it’s

important for carrying the baby around outside safely.

Activity 3: Fill in the blanks with suitable words or phrases.

  1. My favourite pair of shoes is my Reebok running shoes; they         

running or just as casual shoes when I'm relaxing.

  1. Internet chat rooms         discussing all kinds of things, ranging from personal matters, hobbies and interests, relationship problems, and even politics.
  2. The electric light bulb          safe, reliable, and cheap lighting.
  3. Mobile phones          a way for people to communicate and stay in touch with business partners, family, and friends wherever they are.
  4. The Internet has become such a part of everyday life that now it         

every company to be on the Internet and to have email access.

  1. There is an old, yellowing photograph that hangs on the wall in my house. Though it's really old, in my family,          as it's the only photo we have of our great-grandfather.
  2. Ao dai         quite ordinary looking women look more elegant.
  3. My watch has so many functions – it's amazing. Not only is it          telling the time and date, but it can also tell me where I am in the world, how deep underwater I am, and even surf the Internet.
  4. Solar panels          their potential to help save the environment and reverse global warming.

Activity 4: Prepare the second prompt in Activity 2 and tell your partner about it (You should start from prompt 1).

  1. Stage 3

For stage 3 of an object monologue, you should evaluate it Let's look at some more really useful adjectives for evaluation:

Age

Appearance

Value

Quality

state-of-the-art

vivid

overpriced

high-quality

innovative

striking

expensive

reliable

fashionable

colourful

costly

unreliable

advanced

eye-catching

dear

dependable

brand-new

attractive

reasonable

poorly made

cutting-edge

good value

well-made

modern

realistic

economical

low-quality

outdated

charming

reasonably priced

poor-quality

old-fashioned

ugly

low-cost

dated

unattractive

cheap

unfashionable

unappealing

a waste of money

antique

unrealistic

Use

Importance

Size/Weight

Fun

Speed

practical

essential

compact

enjoyable

sluggish

convenient

vital

bulky

fantastic

slow

useful

indispensable

heavy

beneficial

fast

useless

crucial

light

delightful

speedy

impractical

needless

thick

pleasant

quick

informative

dispensable

thin

enlightening

superfluous

soft

educative

unnecessary

hard

helpful

Examples:

  • My laptop is quite old now, so although it seemed an absolutely cutting-edge piece of technology when I bought it, it’s relatively sluggish compared to other computers now.
  • Despite being extremely costly, airplanes provide passengers with a convenient, safe and

economical way to travel.

Activity 5: Match the adjectives for evaluation on the left with their synonyms/meanings on the right.

  1. outdated
  2. economical
  3. unreliable
  4. state-of-the-art/innovative/cutting-edge
  5. vital/indispensable
  6. striking
  7. reasonably priced
  8. well made
  9. practical
  10. informative
  11. superfluous
  12. sluggish
  13. dear
  1. new; using new ideas and/or technology
  2. old; old-fashioned
  3. attractive; easily noticed
  4. bad-quality; easily breaking
  5. good-quality
  6. cheap
  7. good value
  8. expensive
  9. useful; helping solve problems
  10. not needed; unnecessary
  11. essential; extremely important
  12. providing a lot of information
  13. slow

When you evaluate an object, you may want to mention more than one thing. Here are linking phrases to talk about the uses of an object or to evaluate an object.

Linking Phrases

for uses

Examples

In addition to …..

also

In addition to being a worker’s tool, a computer also provides people

with the ability to communicate worldwide.

Besides        also

The subway is a great means of transport because besides being more

environmentally friendly, it also helps reduce traffic.

As well as ……

also

I really valued the scarf my mother knitted me because as well as

keeping me warm, it also reminded me of her love for me.

Not only ………

but also

The electronic dictionary I have not only has millions and millions of

definitions, but also has recordings of native speakers saying the words.

Linking Phrases

for Evaluation

Examples

Although …….

(still)

I prefer Van Gogh’s Crows over Cornfields although Sunflowers is

much more famous.

Despite ………

(still)

Despite buses always being crowded, they’re still the cheapest and most

convenient way to travel.

Even though …..

Even though it has caused many problems, the invention of gunpowder

is extremely important historically.

Apart from ……..

Apart from the very low battery power, my new mobile phone is

excellent.

Activity 6: Use linking phrases to evaluate the objects mentioned below

  1. a mobile phone
  2. jeans
  3. a photo / picture
  4. a household appliance (microwave, fridge, washing machine,…)
  5. a sofa

Activity 7: Prepare the third prompt in Activity 2 and tell your partner about it. (You should start from prompt 1).

  1. Stage 4

For stage 4 of an object monologue, you must: Say why it is important and how you feel about it. Let's look at some more useful words and expressions for attachment to objects:

  1. Adjectives for how an object makes you feel:

nostalgic

sentimental

homesick

inspired

intrigued

fascinated

enthusiastic

delighted

thrilled

exhilarated

relieved

relaxed

  1. Expressions for how an object makes you feel:
  • It makes me feel ……
  • It makes me think of/about ……
  • Whenever I (do something), I feel ………
  • It reminds me of ……………..
  • I couldn’t bear to part with …………….
  • It’s important to me because ………….
  • It’s indispensable to me because ……….

Examples:

  • My new mobile phone, with all its gadgets, makes me feel delighted that my life is getting better and better.
  • My car is important to me because without it I wouldn't be able to do my job.
  • I'm quite sentimental about my teddy bear because it reminds me of my happy childhood in England.
  • Whenever I read a novel by Stephen King, I feel enthusiastic about writing something

Activity 8: Write the words below in the correct spaces.

inspired

intrigued by

nostalgic

relaxed

sentimental

thrilled

  1. I like to sit in front of my TV and watch my favourite programmes while eating my dinner or drinking tea; it makes me         .
  2. I'm quite          about my father's bike, which is why I've kept for so many years even though it's really old and actually not very nice to ride.
  3. I am         Cai Guo-Qiang's works of art using stuffed wolves. Although they are a bit strange, and I'm not sure if I understand them, these sculptures make me think about many different things when I look at them.
  4. Going home makes me feel          because I always think of all the things that my brother and I did together when we were growing up.
  5. They say Christmas is all about giving, not receiving, and I couldn't agree more. When I gave my daughter a doll last Christmas, it was great to see how          she was to have her own little “person” to play with.
  6. After I watched the movie Schindler's List, I was         to try to make the world a better place.

Activity 9: Prepare the final prompt in Activity 2 and tell your partner about it. (You should start from prompt 1).

Activity 10: Using the answer order above, put the following extracts from a model answer into the correct order.

  1. I think mobile phones are an extremely practical piece of equipment to have. Not only mobile phones are used for talking to people and sending text messages but also for surfing the Web, keeping a diary and even as an alarm clock! Some of the most expensive mobile phones are bought by people who want to show off and display their wealth they're often a status symbol
  2. If I had to organize trips out with my friends a few days in advance or contact friends who live far away by letter, life just wouldn't be as much fun. I think that everyone has got used to simply picking up their mobile phone and communicating immediately. As for me, I couldn't bear to part with my mobile phone. It gives me so much independence and freedom, and the games are great too!
  3. Today a mobile phone is an essential piece of technology for everyone, which is used every day. I last used my mobile phone just before this speaking test. My mum sent me a message to wish me luck! Despite being slightly more expensive than a landline, mobile phones are so useful and convenient that many people simply couldn't do without one.
  4. I'd like to talk about mobile phones. As you know, mobile phones nowadays are very light, compact and sleek telephones made of plastic, which can be carried everywhere very conveniently. My parents bought me my first mobile phone one Tet holiday when I was a teenager and I've had one ever since.

  1. Exam practice Part 1

  1. Do you like perfume?
  2. How often do you wear perfume?
  3. Do you give perfume to others as a present?
  4. Do you use a lot of money on perfume?
  5. What does perfume mean to you?

Part 2

LESSON 11 – WRITING MIXED CHART

  1. Understanding mixed charts

In the IELTS Writing Task 1, Multiple Charts / Graphs (Mixed Charts) is a type of test that combines two charts providing different information, these two charts may be the same or different. To complete this type of test well, you need to clearly understand the comparative information between the data, and comment on the similarities and differences of the two charts.

Common types of Mixed Charts:

  • Table with pie chart
  • Table with line chart
  • Table with bar chart
  • Pie chart with line chart
  • Pie chart with bar chart
  • Line chart with bar chart

Example:

  • Table with line chart

At first glance at the question, candidates may be confused because of the appearance of 2 or more different charts. However, the essence of the hybrid chart type is extremely simple: Candidates only need to analyze each given chart type individually and place each chart in a separate body segment – because of the informational nature of the chart. Each chart usually differs in composition and units. Therefore, combining or comparing information between them in the same body paragraph is impossible.

PRACTICE 1

Look at the advice from two IELTS students in this table. Tick the advice you think is more logical and would make it easier to write a clear answer.

Student 1’s advice

Student 2’s advice

Try to be as clever as possible in

Keep it clear and simple. Write

the introduction to impress the

something        like:        The        bar        graph

examiner. Something like: Both

shows the most popular films ... and

Introduction

these        charts        provide        different

then use a linker and explain the

information        about        the        film

second graph clearly:... while the

industry        in  America,  including

pie        chart        illustrates        how        much

popular films and ...

money ...

Overview

Write about as many parts of the graph as possible. I start by writing about the first thing I see,

e.g. the action films, then write about comedy next, etc., but you

have to write really quickly!

Study both graphs carefully first and then pick out a total of two or three pieces of key information to write about, e.g. The most popular type of film was ... These act as a

useful summary of the charts.

Write about both charts together in

Write two separate paragraphs. Start

one paragraph. This way, you can

by writing about the first chart, then

Writing about

compare the information as you

write another paragraph about the

the details

write, and it looks much more

second        chart.        You        can        include

impressive.

comparisons        in        the        second

paragraph.

Keep your introduction clear and logical by writing about the first chart and then the second; demonstrate your ability to use linking language here.

The overview should be a summary of the most useful pieces of information in the chart. If it is a static chart, think about the highest / lowest values. If it is a dynamic chart, focus on the trend over the period.

Writing separate paragraphs about each chart is a simple way to make sure what you write is clear and logical. You can still score very well doing this. If you try to mix everything together, you may risk confusing yourself and the examiner.

  1. Using numerical comparatives

To add style and flexibility to the way you write about and compare information in Task 1, you can also start sentences using a numerical comparative:

‘be + half / twice / three times / four times + as + adj’

Running is twice as popular as doing yoga

PRACTICE 2

Look at the bar chart and complete the sentences below using the words in the box. Then study the grammar structure in each one.

  1. Action movies are.        as popular as comedies for men.
  2. Thrillers are.        as popular as romantic comedies among men.
  3. Science-fiction films and westerns are only        as popular as comedies among

men.

PRACTICE 3

Use the same structures to write sentences to compare these pairs.

  1. comedies / action movies

  1. westerns / romantic comedies

  1. comedies / science fiction

Another structure for numerical comparatives is:

twice / three times / four times as many + [a] + V + than + [b], in which [a] and [b] are two subject we are trying to compare

PRACTICE 4

The same word is missing in these three sentences. Is it as, than or for?

  1. Twice as many men said they liked action movies        comedies.
  2. Three times as many men said they enjoy watching thrillers comedies ................. romantic
  3. Four times as many men prefer watching action films ..................... both westerns and science-fiction movies.

  1. Describing numbers

When writing a Task 1 answer, it is important to describe numbers and data in different ways to avoid repetition. You will be given credit for doing this, as it will show you have a wider range of vocabulary.

PRACTICE 5

Look at the graph about Bernie's Buns and Lovely Loaves and answer these questions.

  1. How many doughnuts does Bernie's Buns sell on average?         
  2. How many doughnuts does Lovely Loaves sell?         
  3. What is the total number of toasted-sandwich sales in Bernie's Buns?         

PRACTICE 6

Compare your answers with a partner. Does your partner have the same three answers? How would you write about this data in words? Compare ideas.

PRACTICE 7

Match these descriptions (a-d) to the questions in        PRACTICE 6 (1-3). One is not necessary.

  1. approximately 135         
  2. about 40         
  3. between 20 and 30         
  4. just over 120         

PRACTICE 8

Write a short description for this information from the chart.

  1. cake sales at Lovely Loaves

  1. rolls sold in Bernie's Buns

  1. cookies bought in Bernie's Buns

  1. How to write

  1. Writing an introduction

To write the introduction for a Mixed Chart, you will need to apply the introductory techniques from all the essay types you have learned before.

Specifically, the introduction for a Mixed Chart is generated by combining two types of introductions. You will write the introduction for Chart 1, then connect it to the introduction for Chart 2 using the connecting words "and" or "while."

For example: The bar chart below shows the numbers of men and women attending various evening courses at an adult education centre in the year 2009. The pie chart gives information about the ages of these course participants.

1st graph Introduction

The bar chart illustrates the quantity of males and females who went

to evening courses at an adult education centre in 2009

Connective word

and / while

2nd graph Introduction

The pie graph shows the percentage of age groups of these course

members

Introduction: The bar chart illustrates the quantity of males and females who went to evening courses at an adult education centre in 2009 while the pie graph shows the percentage of age groups of these course members.

  1. Writing an overview

To write an overview for mixed charts, you need to select the most prominent information / data of each chart to introduce in this section. Important information you can write in the Overview section includes:

  • General trend of the data over time (Does the chart tend to increase or decrease, remains the same or fluctuates continuously?).
  • Highest / lowest figures provided.
  • The difference between the figures provided.

Avoid introducing all the data and informational aspects of both charts because of time and word limits (you can only write about 150 words in 20 minutes), so choose the data that are most outstanding to put in the overview.

Depending on the chart type, you can find correlations between them by answering the following questions:

  • What information does each chart present to the reader?
  • What is the period of the chart?
  • What is the most prominent feature of each chart type?
  • Is there anything in common in the two graphs?
  • What is the relationship between the two graphs (if any)?

You should write one sentence for each chart and connect these sentences using “and” or “while / meanwhile”.

Example:

Overall, the number of tourists visiting to and from Finland rose dramatically over the period of 20 years, and the figure of Finland residents was always higher than that of Finland visitors. It can also be seen that France is the most popular tourist destination, followed by Spain.

PRACTICE 9

Write an overview for the chart below.

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

  1. Selecting and grouping information in the body paragraphs

In the body part, candidates should not combine the data analysis of both charts at the same time because the units of measurement in the chart types are often not the same, so it is difficult to choose a point to compare. In addition, Task 1 only accounts for one-third of the score, so spending more than 20 minutes on Task 1 will interfere with the completion of Task 2, which accounts for two-thirds of the total score. Therefore, the most optimal solution in the form of mixed charts combined chart is to analyze each chart one by one in turn.

For the body part, you can divide it into two sections, each analyzing each chart separately. You can apply the following structure:

Body 1: Describe in detail 2 main points in chart 1 Body 2: Describe in detail 2 main points in chart 2

If the chart is a static chart, try to compare categories. If the chart is a dynamic one, try to

describe the trend over the period.

A few things you need to keep in mind when writing the body section:

  • Because the amount of information provided in mixed charts is quite large, you should not describe both charts in the same paragraph because this will lead to a lack of logic, lack of close links between ideas, and make the reader hard to understand.
  • Do not state your personal opinion.

  1. Practice

The charts below show reasons for travel and the main issues for the travelling public in the US in 2009.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

STEP 1: Write an introduction

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 2: Write an overview (Give an overview statement for each chart. Identify whether the graph is static or dynamic to write the appropriate overview.

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 3: Describe the first chart

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

STEP 4: Describe the second chart

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

………………………………………………………………………………………………………

LESSON 12 – SPEAKING

IELTS SPEAKING PART 2 – DESCRIBE A PAST EVENT

  1. Sample questions

In this lesson, you will learn how to give a monologue about a past event. Typical IELTS Part Two questions about an object include:

  1. Talk about a party you attended.
  2. Talk about a stage in your life that you enjoyed most.
  3. Talk about a sports event you attended.
  4. Talk about a journey you have been on.
  5. Talk about a story you heard as a child.
  6. Talk about a time when you were late for something.
  7. Talk about something you did that helped you learn a language. Here is a cue card in IELTS Speaking Part 2

  1. Structure of an answer

The prompts of each cue card can vary, but to give a good monologue about a past event, here are some basic stages you can follow:

Stage 1: Say what it was and when it happened.

Stage 2: Say why it happened, where it happened, and who was there.

Stage 3: Say what happened.

Stage 4: Say why the event was special and how you feel/felt about it.

  1. Useful language

  1. Stage 1

For stage 1 of a past event monologue, you should say what it was and when it happened.

Obviously, the first thing you should do when beginning your monologue about a past event is to say what type of event it was. Look at the following words and phrases:

Stories

Competitions / Sports

Learning a Language

Journeys

Parties

Television

children’s story

sports match

class

school trip

birthday party

TV program

bedtime story

boxing match

activity

educational trip

housewarming party

TV drama

novel

sports competition

exercise

road trip

hen-party

TV show

play

athletics competition

role-play

daytrip

stag-party

soap opera

poem

chess competition

summer camp

holiday/vacation

wedding reception

documentary

film

speech contest

English corner

family holiday

ball

comedy

opera

the Olympic games

friendly game

tour

fable

the Asian games

class discussion

romantic weekend away

fairy tale

debate

legend

As well as the above, you can also use the following phrases to say what the event was: the time (that/when) + did something

...the time when I saw an interesting story on TV...

...the time that my friends and I went on a day trip...

...the time I went to the Houston Rockets...

the first time + did something

...the first time I learned to ride a bike...

...the first time I played chess...

...the first time I flew in a plane…

Activity 1: Write the words and phrases below in the correct spaces.

fairy tale

Legend

poems

role play

speech contest

romantic weekend away

the first time

the time when

  1. I would like to talk about                 I went abroad. My boyfriend and I went to Rome for а         and he proposed to me. Since then, we've had many such short trips.
  2. I want to tell you about the         of King Arthur. It's a very old story, though it's probably not true.
  3. I'd like to speak about          I rode my motorcycle for hundreds of kilometres around inner Mongolia. It was fantastic.
  4. One thing that really helped me to learn Spanish was the time that I competed in a Spanish         As well as giving a long talk, we also had to recite famous

        and act in a         with the other contestants.

  1. The story I really like is the         "Cinderella”, which is about a girl with two ugly sisters who marries a prince.

Activity 2: Here is a cue card in IELTS Speaking Part 2

Prepare the first prompt and tell your partner about it.

  1. Stage 2

For stage 2 of a past event monologue, you should say why it happened, where it happened, and who was there.

Obviously, when you are talking about a past event, you need to say where it happened. To do this well, you need to use prepositions of location correctly.

Remind yourself of these prepositions of location:

in + an enclosed or larger place

...in my house...

...in Vietnam...

at + a specific place or location

...at the market...

...at the centre of the page...

on + a surface or road

...on the highway...

...on the wall...

over / above + a certain place or location

...above the building...

...over the bridge...

next to / beside / by + a certain place or location

...by the lake...

...next to the post office...

...beside a Chinese restaurant...

opposite / across from+a certain place or location

...opposite the bank...

...across from the drugstore...

between + two places or locations

...between Saigon and Ha Noi...

...between the mountains...

in front of + a certain place or location

...in front of my house...

...in front of the Rex Hotel...

outside of (a town / city)

...outside of Ho Chi Minh City...

near (to)

...near the zoo...

...near (to) London...

far from

...far from home...

...far from the gas station…

Activity 3: Write the appropriate prepositions of the location to complete the sentences.

  1. I was sitting …………. the living room when my mother told me a great documentary was going to be        TV.
  2. An interesting story I heard as a child was about Yu Gong, who lived ……a mountain.
  3. I was later for the meeting than anyone else because I lived so        the office. Ben's

house, on the other hand, is just        where we work.

  1. I once went to a fantastic party        the beach.
  2. The basketball tickets my brother bought were fantastic; there were only a few metres

…        our seats and the basketball players.

  1. A great journey I had a few years ago was when my wife and I flew in a helicopter

…        the Grand Canyon in the USA.

  1. I remember having my photograph taken        the Great Wall when a bird landed on

my head.

  1. Last year I went to Can Gio and visited the Mangrove Forest just        Ho Chi Minh

City.

Most past events native speakers talk about involve other people as in the above model answers. You should similarly use relationship, occupation and group words to describe the people involved.

We've already looked at some words of relatives, occupations and social positions (Person Monologue Stage 1, Language Step 1). The following table contains a few of these words to remind you, as well as words to describe groups of people.

Relatives

Occupations

Relationships

Groups

grandparents

accountant

friend of a friend

a crowd of people

aunt

waiter/waitress

next-door neighbour

loads of people

uncle

musician

colleague

a big group of people

(sport) supporters

party-goers

a tour group

audience

guests

passengers

players

You can also use the following structure to introduce and describe the people in your past event monologue:

person + relative clause Example:

  • Susan, who was an accountant with HSBC, was waiting for me outside.
  • My grandfather, who was a very kind and gentle man, got so angry that he...
  • All of the party-goers, who had been dancing all night decided to go to another bar.

Activity 4: Combine the following sentences. For each, write one sentence that combines both items of information using a relative clause.

For example: Many students had been studying hard. They all decided to have a party after their exams.

=> All of the students who had been studying hard decided to have a party after their exams.

  1. Simon gets carsick very easily. He felt very ill on the school bus one day.

  1. Susan is very forgetful. She forgot her handbag.

  1. Many tennis fans didn't manage to buy tickets. They all watched the match on TV screens outside.

  1. Ralph was a friendly old man. He used to talk to me every day on my way home from school.

  1. Lots of passengers hadn't bought a ticket. They were thrown off the bus.

  1. Some members of the tour group were American. They didn't understand what I said.

Activity 5: Prepare the second prompt in Activity 2 and tell your partner about it.

  1. Stage 3

For STAGE 3 of a past event monologue, you should say what happened.

When describing a past event, you need to use the past simple accurately. You should also use sequence markers to structure your monologue - this makes it clear what order things happened in and also makes you sound much more like a native speaker.

Look at the following useful sequence markers:

To start with

As soon as

So

Next

In the end

At the beginning

Immediately

Afterwards

Soon after

Finally

At first

Straight away

Following that

Shortly after

By the time that

Following from that

Then

After that

Examples:

  • To start with, I felt nervous, but after a few dances I relaxed and in the end, had a really great time.
  • As soon as we entered the stadium, we realized we were very early.
  • I watched a documentary about wild animals a few years ago. Following that, I decided not to eat meat anymore because I think it’s cruel.

Activity 6: Choose the appropriate sequence markers from the choices below to complete the sentences.

  1. I remember when I started learning Italian by using a CD.                 , I found it very useful and I learnt a lot quickly. But         , when I went to Italy and tried to speak Italian, I had lots of problems and realized it wasn't a good way to learn a language.
  1. To start with; as soon as
  2. At first; next
  3. At the beginning; finally

  1. The party started at 7 p.m., but I was really late.         I got there, most of the guests already left.
  1. By the time that
  2. As soon as
  3. Immediately

  1. I got on a bus in Tokyo to go to Kyoto but         leaving the bus station, we crashed into a car.
  1. following that
  2. shortly after
  3. afterwards

  1. At school there was an organised trip to the Cu Chi Tunnels.         we ate ice cream and sang songs on the way home.
  1. So
  2. Next
  3. Afterwards
  1. I really loved the end of my high school although there were lots of exams.

         it was really hard work,         I was tired all the time.                  I got used to the excitement of the exams and rushing to write so much, and found that I actually enjoyed the exams!

  1. At the beginning; then; Following that
  2. To start with; so; Then
  3. At first; following that; In the end

  1. In the story, Goldilocks eats the bears' porridge.                 , she feels really tired and sleeps in one of their beds.         , the three bears come home and find her.
  1. Soon afterwards; In the end
  2. As soon as; Next
  3. Following that; So

Activity 7: Prepare the third prompt in Activity 2 and tell your partner about it.

  1. Stage 4

For stage 4 of an object monologue, you should say why it is important and how you feel about it.

Expressions for Conclusion

Expressions for Conclusion

Examples

The (event) taught me that………

Writing this letter and the effect it had on my friend

taught me that making just small signs that you care about someone can have a big impact on their life.

The (event) was important to/for

me because ……..

This trip was important to me because I learnt a lot about

travelling alone and staying safe.

Through this experience, I learnt

the importance of ………

Through this experience, I learnt the importance of

studying as well as I could, and not being lazy.

I will always remember …….

I will always remember that sunny afternoon in the park

with my boyfriend.

I will never forget …….

I will never forget watching that crazy basketball match

with my father.

Overall,        it        was        a        rewarding

experience……..

Overall, it was a rewarding experience and I learnt a lot.

I’m glad I did it……..

I’m glad I did it. It was a very inspiring experience.

I would love to do it again if

…………….

I would love to do it again if I had the chance.

Although I enjoyed it at that time, I        wouldn’t        do        it        again

because……

Although I enjoyed it at that time, I wouldn’t do it again because I don’t think it would be as much fun now that

I’m older.

In the future, I will …….

In the future, I will try to share the same piece of advice

with others.

Activity 8: Write a suitable concluding phrase for the following sentences.

  1. I'm glad I did it - it was         
  2. Through this experience         not believing everything I am told.
  3.         make sure my children have the opportunity to do the same kind of things.
  4.         that everyone, even people younger than yourself, can give good advice - you just have to listen.
  5.         my 10th birthday party.
  6. Although I enjoyed it at the time,         because looking back I guess it was quite dangerous.
  7. Overall, it was a         
  8. It was         because it made me realize that people everywhere are basically the same.
  9.         if I had the chance.

Activity 9: Prepare the final prompt in Activity 2 and tell your partner about it.

Activity 10: Using the answer order above, put the following extracts from a model answer into the correct order.

  1. In the story there was a boy who was a shepherd. His job was to look after his father's sheep in the fields outside his village, but he found it very boring to be by himself all day.

  1. I want to talk about a story called "The Boy Who Cried Wolf". When I was a child, my mother always used to read me bedtime stories to help me get to sleep. My mother would lie next to me on the bed and read a different story every night. When she was reading, I would often lay my head on her chest and listen to the voices she made for the different characters in the stories. The story I remember best is "The Boy Who Cried Wolf".

  1. The moral of this story is that you shouldn't lie, otherwise, people won't believe you - even when you are speaking the truth. I liked this story as a child and I think it has a good message. I will definitely read this story to my children in the future.

  1. Once, he decided to play a trick on his fellow villagers. He ran into the village shouting "Wolf Wolf! There's a wolf killing my sheep!" Immediately, all the villagers stopped working and ran to the field to help protect the sheep. When they found there was no wolf, the boy laughed at them. Another day, the boy played the same trick on the villagers and again laughed at them when they came running into the field looking for a wolf. One day, a real wolf did get into his field and start attacking his sheep. Again, the boy ran into the village shouting "Wolf Wolf! There's a wolf killing my sheep! " But to his surprise, nobody believed him and all his sheep got killed.

  1. Exam practice Part 1

  1. Where did you play when you were a child?
  2. Did you play at your friend's home?
  3. Did you prefer to play outside or inside when you were young?
  4. Do you think it’s important for children to play outside?

Part 2

LESSON 12 – WRITING PROCESS

  1. Understanding processes

If you have a 'describing a process' task in the exam, you will be given a diagram with a series of pictures. The diagram shows the stages of how something is made or how something works. Typical diagrams are:

  • how chocolate is produced
  • how coffee is grown and produced
  • the life cycle of an animal or insect (e.g. a butterfly) These diagrams can be natural or man-made.

Man-made process

This type of process describes the production process of a specific material or product with human influence. The stages of a man-made diagram will be described in passive language.

Natural process

For this type of test, candidates will have to describe a natural phenomenon (the process of forming a rain, the cycle of water), or the natural life cycle of an animal (the life cycle of a butterfly or frog)

In contrast to the man-made process with the intervention of external factors, in the natural process, individuals develop and move actively, so we use language in an active form to describe.

  1. How to write

  1. Using the present simple passive to describe a man-made process

When you write about a man-made process, one of the main tenses you need is the present simple passive. You make it with:

object + to be + past participle of the verb

Example: The tea leaves are put into boxes, then the boxes are delivered to supermarkets.

If it is a natural process, you will mainly use present simple active.

PRACTICE 1

Read these pairs of sentences. Which in each pair sounds more natural? Why?

  1. a. A lorry driver delivers boxes of tea to supermarkets.

b. Boxes of tea are delivered to supermarkets by lorry.

  1. a. The tea leaves are picked and put into boxes.

b. A farm worker picks the tea leaves and puts them in boxes.

When you write about processes, use an active verb for:

  • natural processes: The sun shines, and the plants grow.

Use a passive for:

  • processes where who does the action is not important: The tea leaves are picked.
  • the stages of producing something: The tea is dried, and then packed into boxes.

PRACTICE 2

Complete this table of common irregular past participles.

verb

past participle

verb

past participle

grow

grown

hold

sow

grind

sell

put

take

cut

wrap

weave

PRACTICE 3

Complete these sentences with the passive form of the verb in brackets.

  1. Oranges are exported from Spain to colder countries in Europe. (export)
  2. Coffee beans        in a machine, in order to make coffee powder. (grind)
  3. Rice        into bags and then delivered to supermarkets. (put)
  4. Coconuts        from the trees, and then exported to other countries. (cut)
  5. The bars of chocolate        in silver paper and put into boxes. (wrap)

PRACTICE 4

Use the correct form of the verbs in the box to complete the paragraph below about the first half of this process.

Tea 1. is grown in India and China. In the first stage, the tea seeds 2        by the farmer,

and then the sun 3........................, and the seeds 4...................... into large tea plants. At this

point, the tea leaves 5 ......................and 6.......................in a basket, and then they 7......................... on a tray in the sun to dry. The next step is that the dried tea leaves 8...........................into boxes, and then the boxes 9 ..................... onto a lorry, and then 10

.        to supermarkets, where customers buy them.

  1. Linking stages together

When you write about a process, you need to join the stages together in different ways, to make your answer more interesting.

PRACTICE 5

Write these linking words and phrases in the correct column of the table below according to their meaning.

Then

First of all

At this point

and then

The first step is that

Finally

After that

Following this

Subsequently

The next step is that

Initially

after which

The last step is

To begin with

The following step is that

Next…

The first stage is…

The last stage is…

Then

PRACTICE 6

Put these steps in the process of making a cup of tea in order.

  1. Pour the water into the cup.
  2. Fill the kettle with water.
  3. Add milk and sugar.
  4. Leave the tea for two minutes.
  5. Boil the kettle.
  6. Drink the tea.
  7. Take the kettle off the stove.
  8. Put a tea bag or tea leaves in the cup.

PRACTICE 7

Use the linking phrases in PRACTICE 5 to describe the process in PRACTICE 6 to a partner, or write it down.

Example: The first step is that you fill the kettle with water, and then you…

  1. Giving extra information about a stage

To extend and improve your answer, you can describe what happens in a stage, and then add some extra details or explain why it happens.

The tea leaves are put on the ground in the sun, so that they can be dried.

You can use relative clauses or phrases and clauses of purpose

PRACTICE 8

Match the stages (1-4) to the corresponding extra details (a-d).

  1. The boxes of tea are delivered to supermarkets,
  1. which gives them extra flavour.

  1. The sun shines,        b. where        they        are        put        on        the shelves to be sold.

  1. Salt and sugar are added to the tomatoes,

c. in order to be made into sugar for cooking.

  1. The sugar cane is taken to a factory,        d.  which helps the plants to grow.

PRACTICE 9

Join each pair of sentences using the words in brackets.

  1. The fruit is sent to a factory. It is put into cans there. (where) The fruit is sent to a factory, where it is put into cans.
  2. The biscuits are put in the oven. They are cooked. (in order to be)

  1. The farmer waters the plants. This makes them grow more quickly. (which)

  1. The mushrooms are stored in a dark room. This helps them to stay fresh. (so that)

By giving extra information about a stage, you can write enough words for the required topic.

  1. Writing the introduction and overview

As in other types of Task 1 question, in the introduction to a process, you need to rewrite the question in your own words. There are several ways in which you can do this:

  • The pictures illustrate how tea is produced.
  • The pictures show the steps involved in making tea.
  • The diagram highlights the process by which tea is produced.

PRACTICE 10

Write an introductory sentence for these Task 1 questions.

  1. The diagram shows how to produce potato chips.

  1. The pictures show how people get a driving license.

You can also add an overview sentence to give a short summary of the process. This can mean describing the:

  • number of stages, and listing the first and last stages;
  • different sections of the process (e.g. producing tea/making a cup of tea)

PRACTICE 11

Complete the mini-overview below for the tea-making process using the words in the box.

There are eighteen 1 ................... in the process, 2 ..................... 3        the tea seeds in the

ground 4 ......................... 5        nice cup of tea.

  1. Practice- Describe a process

  1. Man-made process

The pictures below show how tea is produced. They also illustrate the process of making a cup of tea.

Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features.

  1. Natural process.

Sometimes a process question can be a lifecycle or an insect or animal. However, you just have to follow the steps to write a man-made process. Pay attention to steps where you have to use active verbs.

You can look through your homework with your teacher and the whole class to figure out what you need to do with a natural process.

LESSON 13 – SPEAKING

IELTS SPEAKING PART 2 – DESCRIBE A PLACE

  1. Sample questions

In this lesson, you will learn how to give a monologue about a place. Typical IELTS Part Two questions about a place include:

  1. Talk about a flat or house you would like to own one day.
  2. Talk about your ideal home.
  3. Talk about a shopping centre or mall you have visited.
  4. Talk about a place where people can do sports.
  5. Talk about a place you know where people go to listen to music.
  6. Talk about a friend or family member's house you know and like.
  7. Talk about a museum you have visited.
  8. Talk about a historic place in your country.
  9. Talk about a lake or river you know about or have seen.

Here is a cue card in IELTS Speaking Part 2

  1. Structure of an answer

The prompts of each cue card can vary, but to give a good monologue about a place, here are some basic stages you can follow:

Stage 1: Say what it is and where it is

Stage 2: Say what it looks like.

Stage 3: Say what its purpose is.

Stage 4: Say why it is important and how you feel about it.

  1. Useful language

  1. Stage 1

For stage 1 of a place monologue, you should say what it is and where it is. The first thing you need to do when giving a monologue about a place is to say what kind of place it is.

Here are some more really useful words for different types of places:

Religious

Tourism

Shopping

Accommodation

Natural

Leisure

Entertainment

Mosque

Tourist attraction

Shopping mall

House

Scenic spot

Leisure centre

Nightclub

Temple

Historic site

Shopping centre

Flat/apartment

Park

Sports ground

Theatre

Church

Historic building

Plaza

Mansion

Botanical garden

Stadium

Cinema

Cathedral

Palace

Market

Campsite

Nature reserve

Football pitch

Concert hall

Religious building

Museum

Discount store

Youth hostel

Countryside

Sports field

Music hall

Examples:

Let me tell you about a theatre I once saw when I was travelling...

I would like to talk about the Lavender Fields in Norfolk, which is a very popular tourist attraction. I'm going to talk about a lovely little park in the countryside outside London.

Activity 1: Match the types of places on the left with the activities people do there on the right.

  1. temple        A. where people go shopping and try to haggle to get a good price
  2. market        B. where people can get fit and play sports

  1. museum        C. where people can go to listen to music and dance
  2. nature reserve        D. where people can enjoy trees, mountains and rivers
  3. leisure centre        E. where people go to pray/worship gods

  1. mansion        F. where people can see very old and interesting objects
  2. nightclub        G. a very large house where rich people live

Remember to say where their place is located immediately after you have said what the place is – this helps to introduce the place you are describing.

Remind yourself of these essential prepositions of location:

Prepositions of Location

Examples

In + an enclosed or large place

In Ho Chi Minh City

In the countryside

In the middle of nowhere

At + a certain place or location

At the top of the mountain

At the end of the street

On + a surface or road

On the fifth floor

On a main road

On the outskirts of the city

Over/above + a certain place or location

Above a Japanese restaurant

Over Ba Dinh Square

Next to/beside/by + a certain place or location

By the seaside

Next to the Bell Tower

Beside Xuan Huong Lake

Opposite to/across from + a certain place or location

Opposite to my favourite restaurant

Across from Ninh Kieu Park

Between + two places or locations

Between the mountains and the sea

In front of + a certain place or location

In front of the main historic building

Outside of + a certain place

Outside of Can Tho City

Near (to) + a certain place

Near to Laos

Near the sea

Far from + a certain place

Far from Vietnam

Far from the city centre.

  1. My gym is located         my office. When I work, I can see all the people exercising and weightlifting. It makes me feel really guilty if I haven't gone for a while.

  3. in

  2. far from
  3. beside

  1. Many different bands and musicians have played         that concert hall.
  1. of
  2. on
  3. at

  1. The Bell Tower is in an awkward position to visit because it's right        a busy road junction.
  1. next to
  2. on
  3. opposite
  1. I like to go to Vincom Centre because it's         my school; I can go shopping there on my way home from class.
  1. on
  2. between
  3. near

  1. The most amazing house I've ever seen was        a forest; it was made of wood and was built high in the trees.
  1. in
  2. on
  3. at

  1. There is a famous tourist site just         the city centre.
  1. between
  2. in front of
  3. outside of

  1. I would love to own a small house         the coast so I could fall asleep to the sound of the sea.
  1. in
  2. at
  3. on

Activity 3: Here is a cue card in IELTS Speaking Part 2

Prepare the first prompt and tell your partner about it.

  1. Stage 2

For STAGE 2 of a place monologue, you should say what it looks like. To describe the place of your monologue well, you should say something about its size.

Have a look at the following really useful size and shape words

Big

Small

Width

Height

Length

Huge/large

Little

Narrow

Towering

Long

Massive

Tiny

Wide

High

Short

Vast

Minute

Broad

Tall

Winding

Enormous

Minuscule

Thin

Short

Endless

Gigantic

Cramped

Thick

Low

Far-reaching

Immense

Squat

Examples:

A vast mountain range / landscape / lake / desert

A massive / gigantic / huge / enormous / immense building / house / shopping complex /

room

A cramped room / house / dormitory A broad avenue / street

A tall/high building / mountain

A winding path / country road / mountain pass

A tiny /minuscule / incredibly small object / doorway / window

You can also use the following phrases to talk about the dimensions of the place:

  • (number) metres / kilometres by (number) metres / kilometres

Ba Dinh Square is 320 metres by 100 metres.

  • (number) metres / kilometres square

The size of Ba Be Lake in Bac Kan is about 6.5 kilometres square.

As you can see, the model answers in the previous part include words and expressions to accurately describe the appearance and character of a place. You should use them in your monologue to sound much more like a native.

Light

Dark

Ugly

Examples:

A(n) airy / well-lit / light / dingy / horrible room / house / flat / dormitory A dark / gloomy / dank cave / woodland
